editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE VILLAIN, A TRAGEDY Written by T. PORTER Eſq; Foelix et proſperum Scelus Virtus vocatur.
LONDON, Printed for Henry Herringman at the Anchor in the New Exchange, and Samuel Speed at the Rainbow in Fleetſtreet. 1663.

div.head: THE PROLOGUE.
div.l: AS I appear, (me-thinks) I hear ſome ſay,
O, this is He that must excuſe the Play!
They better gueſs than thoſe who think I'm ſent
To dare the Cenſures of th' Impertinent;
Such a Poetique Choler would appear
Just like that Courage which is rais'd by Fear.
But (Gentlemen) in troth I'm only come
To tell ye that the Author is gone home,
To 〈◊〉 your D • om, like ſome poor Couze •• d Wench
That has not Confidence t' out-face the Bench.
We were ſuch Fools as to perſwade his Stay,
But (ſmiling at us) He made haſte away,
And ſaid ye could not ſo much honor lack,
As to ſpeak ill of him behind his back.

list.item: La Bar Gentleman of his Horſe.
Maligni His Major and a Villain.
Bouteſeu Delpeche Lamarch Officers in Briſac's Regiment.
Luyſon A waiting woman to Bellemont.

div.head: ACT 1. SCENE 2.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: YOu have oblig'd me, Sir, in your laſt grant.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: It ſtill has been my ſtudy how to ſerve
A man of Hono • . This is no ſuch favour.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Pardon me, Sir, I do eſteem it highly,
And do once more aſſure you, that your men▪
Shall find the Welcome that the Town affords;
You freely ſhould command all that is here,
From the ſole Merit you your ſelf poſſeſs,
Which with an Obligation I've receiv'd
Lately, and in the perſon of my Friend,
Does doubly claim performance of my Promiſe.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Enough, good Sir:
You make me bluſh, I have not yet deſerv'd
The Honor that you now enrich me with.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: I have done, Sir.
An Officer of yours?
sp.stage: Turns to Beaupres and ſalutes him.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: He is my friend, and in that Office bears
Command o'r all that e'r I ſhall call mine.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: One that is proud to wait upon his worth,
And take the Copy of a gallant man
From his ripe Youth.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Believe me, Sir, your perſon does beſpeak
An expectation in all thoſe that ſee you,
Of what is Great and Generous in a Man.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: You 've read him right.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: I cannot doubt it, Sir:
For Friendſhip in Young-men breeds a delight
In doing great and worthy things, whereby
They may tie faſt the bond of Friendſhip ſworn.
That Prince is happy who in's Army has
Such Rivals unto Virtue and to Honor;
And yet rejoyce when either courts them well.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Your praiſe will make me ſtudy to deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Well, Major, have you yer diſpos'd the men?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: They are all Billited, ſaving ſome few
That were deſign'd unto the place you mention'd.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Make up their Quarters out of thoſe ſame Blanks
My ſervants drew, and yours, my deareſt Friend,
May ſerve for ſix, I know you will not leave me.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Leave that to me; the favour's very great:
You have remov'd the trouble from the place
Th •• ca •• s my Friend its Landlord.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: But not with an intention, 't ſhould be put
Upon your care.
There's room enough, he knows how to diſpoſe them.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: I muſt ſubmit: but pleaſe you all to grace
My houſe and me; and if it do not ſpeak
So large a welcome as my heart does mean,
Blame my poor power, not my want to will.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Pleaſe you to lead the way, we'l follow.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: I'm proud to be your guide in this occaſion. Stops him as he's going.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Sir, I would ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Prethee, Beaupres, go you along,
Tell him he ſhall not long expect our coming.
Now, Major, ſpeak your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Have you deſign'd your Siſter ſhould come here,
And ſtay this Winter-Quarter 'mongſt your Troops?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: You know I have: But prethee why do'ſt ask?
Do'ſt think that Tours is like unto the Camp?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No, but—

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: But what? are there not hundreds more
Of the ſame Quality that reſide here?
My houſe not fifteen Leagues from hence,
Why ſhould I bar her being here this winter?
'Twas but a year ago you wondred much
I would confine her to a Country life,
And ſaid, her breeding was not like my Siſter's,
Though ſhe did want no Maſters could inrich
Her mind and carriage; yet then you thought fit
She ſhould ſee Paris and its Bravery.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I hope my care does give you no offence?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: No, Honeſt Malignii, I know you've been
My friend ſince I writ Man: do but ſpeak
To ſhow the error of your friendly Doubts.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I'm glad you ſo interpret them.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: I know they are:
Do'ſt think our Regiment a ſweeping plague,
That does infect whole Towns it quarters in▪
Or that it breaths the air of Vice on all
The Virgins live in the ſame Horizon?
Ha, ha, ha!
I know they'r Blades, but yet I think they'l ſcarce
Preſume to venture on my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Fie, Sir, I never thought on that.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: What then? I cannot gueſs your meaning.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nor I, till time (which ripens all) diſcloſe it.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Well then let's wait that time:
But now it is decreed ſhe comes,
Beaupres to morrow goes to fetch her hither.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Tis wondrous well and fine.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: What is?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: This Town.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: I, is it not a lovely ſeat?
But this ſame River Loyre is bleſt along
It's bank's with ſeveral of ſuch City's.
Come, come, the Governour will ſtay for us.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I'l wait upon you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: I hope thou wilt.
There is a Captain quarters at my houſe,
Be ſure you bid your Siſters treat him well;
But heark you Sir; I'd have you watch their Waters,
Theſe men of warr will ſtraight-wayes clap a-Board.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: I'l warrant you Father, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: But you muſt ſtill be civil, and give way,
When th' other Officers do come to viſit.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: What do you mean Father, muſt I leave the Room and ſhut the Dore?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Away, you Dunce, I mean you muſt take heed
That you do no ways interrupt diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: I ſhall Sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I ſay you muſt not by no means.
Pox how I ſhall be plagu'd !
Why they will ſtraight perceive thou art ill bred.
I'l ſend thee ſt • aight into the Country,
For here thou wilt be Jeer'd, or may be kill'd
For doing ſome prepoſterous fooliſh thing.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: I fear not that;
But good Sir conſider the ſmallneſs of this ſtock.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why here is more, a Crown in gold.
Be ſure you wear this ſtil but for a ſhow.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: I'l do as does befit a man.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: As does befit a Gudgeon.
Well Sir lets ſee how you will bear your ſelf;
I fear wee ſhall have ſome r • nk tricks o'th' ſchool.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Here comes our Gueſt Father.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: The Maſter of this houſe I think you are?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The man that's honor'd with that title Sir.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Yes 'tis my Father Sir, and I'm his Son.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: I did believe as much.
Sir I muſt beg your p • tience for the trouble
My men and I muſt give you this ſame Winter,
But they ſhall ſtil moſt orderly obſerve
A juſt Decorum which befits the place.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Your men!
Why Sir I hope your whole Troop is not quarter'd
Upon my houſe?

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: Oh no Sir!
I mean my ſervants,
They are men too.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Yes indeed father are they,
The Gentleman ſpeak's truth,
The Captain I ſhould ſay Sir:
I humbly Crave your pardon: 'twas a miſtake.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: O Sir, the fault is not ſo great.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: I hope ſo Sir: I ſhould be loath in any way t'offend.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Hold you your prating;
Sir, you freely may command this houſe,
And him that's owner of't.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: Your ſervant Sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And if in ought my Son can do you Service,
Pray command him too.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: I, or if my Siſters can do you Service,
Pray command them too.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: Sir, I ſhall ſtudy ſtil to be their Servant.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You muſt be prating ſtil.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Why Father, would you not have me civil
To our new gueſt the Captain?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yes, but mark me, and Imitate.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: Are theſe his Siſters
Which he talks of, handſome?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Y'are melancholy Sir;
Shall we walk in and taſt the fruit,
Or rather Juicy ſubſtance of th' laſt Vintage?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Which is to ſay,
Let's crack a Bisket o'r a glaſs of Wine.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: I did conceive as much:
I ſhall wait on you Sir.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: And I will wait on you moſt noble Captain.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: O Lord Sir.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Beaupres to morrow go's to fetch her hither;
'Twas ſo he ſaid.
S'death can he ſtil be blind?
I've known him ſubtil as the Ayr, to find
Anothers ſecret out; and glide
Through the ſmall Pores that guard the heart
And there take view of all that it conceal'd;
Such pow'r his Cunning and diſcourſes had;
But now a Mole, or elſe he ſeems to be ſo.
Hair-brain'd Alecto lend me but one ſnake,
I'l make his heart the paſture to maintain it;
And all yee Furies hold your Torches high,
That they may Sparkle fier to his Eyes,
And his Soul bubble o'r as faſt as yours;
'Twill be a gallant ſlame when his fierce rage
Shoot's forth in Flakes like Aetna in her Labour,
And Beaupres too, that is as hot as hee,
Shall meet that Ardor with an Equal heat;
Oh how my Soul rejoyces when I think on't!
Back, back, yee fooliſh thoughts, of man, and honour,
Y'are but diſeaſes to me, and my Love
Hath long been Peſtered with your Childiſh fears;
That is the D • ity which I adore,
And what doth not conduce to profit that,
Shall ſtil be held Heretical by me.
Ha! What maks him follow me.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Maligni, as e'r thou wer't my Freind,
Excuſe me to my Colonel,
I dare not ſtay, the health's grow ponderous,
For great glaſſes fill'd,
Burthen the ſtomak and make the head light.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Why how now Sir, are you turn'd Flincher too?
Nay then the trick of drinking will grow ſtale:
For ſhame leave not your Colonel ſo.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Why there be ſome more Officers with him,
La'march is there, and Boutefeu I think,
D'elpech is juſt now entr'd, all ask for you,
For me I think they cannot miſs this night;
But if my Colonel ſhould Chance to ask,
Say I was much diſtemper'd, and went home;
Beſids to morrow I muſt be ſtirring early.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: About your Journy?
Tis better far than drinking,
To entertain one's ſelf ſo neer the joy
With thinking of it.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Why? do you find ſuch pleaſure, Sir, in riding?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: To wait on ſuch fair objects, Sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I wonder then you ſpoak not for th' Imployment.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: You had prevented me, or elſe I would.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: You are miſtaken, Sir, my Colonel
Pitch'd upon me, knowing with what joy;
I ſtill was preſt t'o bey, and do him ſervice.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Moſt likely Sir.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Good night, good Major, pray excuſe me this time.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Diſeaſes cloſe your Eyes—
How is my ſoul rack't, when I ſee this man?
And yet my Genius will not give me Leave,
T'attempt my quier, by his ſuddain death;
Something there is that awes me ſtrangely:
Conſcience I'm ſure it is not:
For did he walk with mark and curſe of Heav'n,
To thoſe that ſhould deprive him of his life,
I'd wiſh this hand had don't;
Something I muſt find out, and ſuddenly,
To thruſt him on to Ruine:
His Angel muſt be watchful if he ſcape me.

div.stage: Enter D'orvile as conducting them to the door, Bourefeu, I a'march, Delpe che.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: I am ſorry gentlemen you will not ſtay,

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Tis late Sir,
And our Colonel will want his reſt.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: We fear our trouble has been great already.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: It was an honor you have done my houſe.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: No further, Sir, I pray.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: Sir, I beſeech you leave us here.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I'm ſtill obedient to what you command.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Your humbleſt Servants, Sir.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: Now what ſhall we do?
No acquaintance here, Boutefeu?
Nor you, D'elpeche? Now I think on't better,
Thou art a Puling Lover,
Writ'ſt Verſes, or at leaſt pretend'ſt to't,
I will not go to bed yet▪
What are you for?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I? why any thing.
D'elpeche, haſt e'r a Miſtris here
We may repair to?
Two hours in Town with thee's an Age;
I know thou canſt not want a Miſtris here.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: And do you hope I'l bring you to her?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Why not?
Do'ſt think I would prophane thy Lady Bright
With ſcurvy Courting?

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: Or put thee out of countenance
VVith ſaying things we never did intend,
But yet ſo quaint and new a Dialect,
That ſhe ſhall ſtand amaz'd at our great wit,
And find by proof hereafter • hou h • ſt▪ none.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Why you brace of B • boons,
Do not I know it's a Baudy-houſe you look for▪
You Miſtreſſes? Flanders Mares,
And thoſe extremely ready to be Hors'd,
You'l hardly ſt • y the Courtſhip elſe.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: VVhy where's the pleaſure of it elſe?
Daily to w • it upon my L • dy's Dog,
And pick the Fleas that de moleſt his VVorſhip;
M • ke cringe • to her Picture,
Swear 'tis Heav'n to hear her hum an Air,
Though out of Tune.
If ſhe but ſmile, fall backward in a Rapture;
If frown, fall in a Swoun and break your face.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: Or fit and praiſe the wit ſhe ſhows
In the ingenious chuſing of her colours.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: You ſpeak as if I thus imploy'd my time.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Moſt certainly thou do'ſt.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: Come, come, ſhall's go drink?
For yet I will not go to bed.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Fie, ſie, we're wondrous hot
With Wine already, I could tell ye.
But you are Brutes and will do ſome rude thing.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I ſwear we wo'nt.
What is't, or where, D'elpeche?

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: Why look you, Gentlemen,
I'm lodg'd where Beauties live,
Whoſe eyes will force high capers in your bloods:
Will you prepare your morrow's Viſit
With a quaint Serenade this night?

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: Agreed i'faith; where ſhall we get the Muſick?

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: That I did beſpeak before.
See here, I think they're come.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: What are you, Gentlemen,
The merry Boys, that ſaw a heart in ſunder
With your Rofin?

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.l: This Gentleman beſpoke us here to night.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: I did ſo, pray begin.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.l: What ſhall we play, Sir?

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: the neweſt Ayrs.They play an Ayr or two.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Pox o' theſe fine things;
Can you not play the Siege of Rochel?

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: Fie, Boutefeu, there's a Tune for Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Why then let them play
The Tune we made the Song to th' other night. La'mar. ſings the Tune to the Muſique.

sp.speaker: La'ma.
sp.l: I, I, by any means.
Lum terum, tum, &c.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.l: Oh, Sir, we know the Tune.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Begin then; D'elpeche, you ſhall bear your part.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: My hope is they'l not underſtand us.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: Come, come, I'l begin.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: How happy and free is plunder,
When we care not for Jove nor his Thunder?
Having entred a • own,
The Laſſes go down,
And to their O're-comers lie under.

sp.speaker: Chorus together.
sp.l: Then why ſhould we ſtudy to love, and look pale,
And make long Addreſſes to what will grow ſtale?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: If her fingers be ſoft, long, and ſlender.
When once we have made her to render,
She will handle a Flute
Better far than a Lute,
And make what was ha—rd to grow te—nder,

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Then why ſhould we ſtudy, &c.

sp.speaker: All three ſing this together.
sp.l: When the houſes with • laſhes do glitter,
We can ſever our ſweets from the bitter,
And in that bright night
We can take our delight,
And no Dam'ſel ſhall ſcape but we'l hit her.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Then why ſhould we ſtudy, &c.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: Peace, peace, pray peace,
The window opens.
Play and ſing that I ſent you to night.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.l: We ſhall, • ir.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: Plague o'you 〈◊〉 , ye Dogs,
Cannot your Inſtruments ſtand in Tune
One quarter of an hour?

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l:
Prethee, La'march,
• e ſilent,

lg.l: See where Caliſto wheels about
The Northern Axle-tree of Heav'n,
And ſwift Bootes ſtill does Rout
Before his Laſh the glittering Seven.
View then thoſe Eyes which are more fair
Than any Star that glitters there.
Fair Caſſiopeia, would'ſt thou gain
The Prize of glory in thy Sphere?
Try then to borrow of theſe Twain
Two pair of Eyes that ſhine more clea •
For whilſt they ſparkle here below,
Obſcurer Lights we cannot know.
In nights they far out-ſhine the Moon,
And render them like glorious days,
They may contend at heighth of Noon
To equalize the Sun's bright Rays:
Their Coronet of Hair, though brown,
Does far out-ſhine Ariadne's Crown.
Then gently dart thoſe beams; for know,
How quick and fiercely they ſurprize
The Centinels that expect below
The dawning of your beauteous Eyes.
We are your Plants, and if we thrive,
'Tis by your influence that we live. The window opens quick.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Ladies, do's this pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: Prethee be ſilent.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: Why? have you prepar'd any more tricks for them?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Beſides we ſhould fain hear
The heavenly Muſique of their Voices.
Ladies, can you vouchſafe a Parley?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We can, Sir;
Though that muſt never give you any hopes,
The Fort is to be rendred.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: We ask it not upon thoſe terms.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: If you do Sirs,
Wee'l ſtraight advance our flag of high defiance.

sp.speaker: La'ma.
sp.l: What colour beats it Lady?
Or what Motto?
For it needs muſt be extraordinary,
Since women hold it forth.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: See Sir, the Colour's white,
And for the Motto,
Siſter, what ſhall it bee?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Any thing, the colour ſpeaks it ſelf,
Tis Innocence.

sp.speaker: La'ma.
sp.l: • o are your ſheets Lady.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: And ſhall be ſo ſtil for you Sir.

sp.speaker: La'ma.
sp.l: Say you ſo? why then come doleful death.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: Come, come, La'march we ſhall grow troublſome,
Tis late; Lady's we humbly kiſs your hands.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We are your Servants Sir.Shut to the window.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l:
Why in ſuch h • ſt ••
D'elpeche?
Pox, why did you take leave ſo ſoon?
I was ſtudying of a fine ſpeech: which now y'ave ſpoyl'd.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: No matter, to morrow will ſerve,
I'l teach thee one without book by that time.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I'm much beholding to your Learning Sir.

sp.speaker: Round.
sp.l: Stand, who goes there? Speak to the round.

sp.speaker: La'ma.
sp.l: Friends to the guard.

sp.speaker: Round.
sp.l: I think you are ſome of the officers
That laſt came to Town.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: You are in the right Gentlemen.
But whither ſo faſt this way?

sp.speaker: Round.
sp.l: To the Governor Sir, for the keys,
There is ſome noble man at the gate,
Deſires preſently to be let into, Town.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: Know yee who is?

sp.speaker: Round.
sp.l: No, but he deſires ſtraight to be conducted
To the Governor. Good-night Gentlemen; tis late,

sp.speaker: La'ma,
sp.l: VVe know it Sits.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Come, wee two go together.
D'elpeche, you are at home.

sp.speaker: La'ma
sp.l: Adien Mounſieur; we may I hope,
See theſe Ladies to morrow.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: M • ch may be done, as yee behave your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Adien Formality.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: Good night Swaſh. Bout. and Lama. goe out with muſique playing them to their Lodging.

div.stage: Enter D'orvile, making himſelf ready, and Servants.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: I wonder who't ſhould be thus late?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Some expreſs from Court, Sir.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: I certainly, but what about, I cannot gueſs.
Get things in readineſs,
They ſay, it is a man of Quality.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Shall I wake the Colonel?

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: By no means;
The Complement were ill, to ſtay him here
This night, and trouble him.
Be ſure there be no noyſe made
About his Chamber.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: There ſhall not Sir.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Go then, diſpatch, and let a Room be ſtraight provided,
That he may reſt himſelf.
VVhat ſhould this Summons mean?
I hope the king is well.

div.stage: Enter General, La Barr, and the guard, with lights before 'em.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.l: I hope you'l pardon this diſturbance?

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: The greateſt honour could arive unto me.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.l: La Barr, give the guard to drink.
They'r carefull men, and ought to be rewarded.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: I'm glad you found 'em ſo;
If n • gligent, the blame had all been mine.
But Sir, I hope no evill accident

Is 〈◊〉
• hat you travel now ſo late.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.l: None, I aſſure you Governor.
I had a great deſire to wait upon you,
And free my ſelf from the Tempeſtuous noiſe,
And Turbulent cares, the Court afflicts us with:
I hope all health poſſeſſes your fair Daughter.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: She cannot want it Sir, that has your wiſhes:
But you are weary Sir, and want repoſe.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.l: Indeed I am,
VVe have rid hard to day;
No lodging's to be found in all the Suburbs,
Elſe we had ſpar'd you this nights trouble.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: You then had wrong'd your ſervant much.
But Sir, tis morning, you may break faſt
Before you go to bed.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.l: Not now, for I am wondrous weary.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: I ſhall Conduct you then unto your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Gener.
sp.l: Come, La-Barr, I think thou ſleep'ſt.

div.head: ACT 2. SCENE 1.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: HE's gon,
And may the plagues of hell perſue his ſteps.
How diligent he is to my undoing?
I have ben all this night as watchfull too
As hee; though from a different cauſe:
For mine was malice, and a jealous hate,
That tenterhookt my Eye-lid's, when as ſleep
Did poize 'em down;
Curſe be the Guards that let him forth,
At that dead time of night,
Some trick might elſe have ſtay'd his journey;
And may be her's from comming hither;
I ſhall grow mad to ſee this Beard-leſs boy
Out-rival mee, in what I moſt eſteem.
Oh Bell-mont, too cruel, and too fair!
But yet, I will not fall alone:
That minute, Malignii, thy hopes ſhall leave thee,
Reſolve, all bliſs and comfort ſhall leave her,
Unleſs thy wits with hope ſhall take their flight.
For I am not that curious Coxcomb Lover,
That ſuffers patiently, and will admit
He not deſerves when ſhe does think unfit.
They that can make me ſuffer without pitty,
Deſerve inflictions from my brains requital.
—I have it,—or if that fail,
Boutefeu's an Engine I can ſet a-work.
A blunt, conceited fool—
And for his temper—
I'l mannage him, no Chymiſt with more Art▪
And when I pleaſe, his worſhip flies in Fumo.
But firſt, I'l to my Colonel to move,
All ſails is beſt to catch at ſleeting Love.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: You know I never did refuſe you ought
Was fitting you ſhould ask, or I ſhould grant;
Nor am I ſuch a lealous fool, Charlotte,
To doubt the ſtrength of your fair Education:
But as it is your duty to obey,
So it is mine to tell you freely now
Wherein and how I do expect it from you.
You know what Gueſt arrived here laſt night,
(Whoſe father was the maker of my fortune)
He's young, and has a prefence too too fair,
To truſt a Courtſhip without timely counſel;
I know his aims at you.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: 'Tis more than yet I am acquainted with;
Do you not mean Briſac?

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: No, no, you know I don't;
Or are you ignorant of viſits that concern you?
'Tis Clairmont the young brave General,
Arriv'd here when we were all a-bed.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Truly I did not know ſo much.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: Nor had you no ſuſpition of his coming?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Why do you ask me, Sir?
Do you ſuſpect ſecret intelligence
Twixt him and me? I hope my Honor's fair
In your belief, elſe truly I am wrong'd.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: Nor is it an opinion of thy weakneſs
That draws this counſel from me,
But tender care my love does owe thy youth,
And as a father I do owe my child.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Proceed, dear Sir,
And from the expect a full obedience.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: Know then, (Charlotte) a Maid with beauty ſtor'd,
Ought to be Miſtris of much care and wit,
Not to eſteem the Treaſure of a face
Or body, more than of a fairer mind.
I counſel no neglect of them; but ſtill
With equal labour ſtrive to gain the Prize
Of Beauty's Lawrel, and of being wiſe;
Or elſe your ſob'reſt Looks will ſtill provoke,
And what you meant for Chaſt be conſtru'd Love;
Till you have got repute of all the world
That you are virtuous, as they think you fair:
Then like a Beauteous Field of Corn you'l ſhow,
Which none may reap, though all admire and wiſh,
Till the right Owner calls this Harveſt home.
Nor Love conſents that Beauty's Field lie waſte,
Weed out all Vice, and plant fair Virtue there;
Of all, be warie of an eaſie Faith,
A root that quite deſtroys a Virtuous mind;
The bitter ſeed is Candy'd with ſweet words,
Which when the Sugar's melted all away,
Does ſhoot up into infamy and ruine;
For though that Nature made you to be won,
Yield not till by a fair approach your ta'n.
D'ye underſtand me what I mean by this?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: I ſhall do, Sir, by that time you have ended.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: In ſhort, I'd have you know
In fewer words, without all Parables,
I am not ignorant why Clairmont comes hither,
And though he does pretend a wearineſs
Of buſineſs, and the crowding of a Court,
'Tis to ſee you he comes, and ſo he'l tell you:
Thus far I know: but whether ill or well
He means in his addreſſes, you'l beſt learn—
In fine, your Honor now (which ſtill is mine)
Depends upon upon the trial of your virtue,
And if your beauty could attract his eyes,
Your virtue try'd will tie 'em conſtant to you.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: All theſe have been the Leſſons of my Mother,
And I may hope that I am perfect in 'em.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: I hope ſo too, Charlotte; and ſo I leave you,
For I do hear Clairmont's already up.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: What wondrous pains our Parents ſeem to take?
Who though they gave us Natures, cannot frame
What they themſelves have made, obedient to them.
I thank m • Stars, mine is not ſo deprav'd,
That I need bluſh the owning of its paſſions.
But why my Soul, Image of Heavenly Good,
Should ſtoop to Earth, and h • arken to the World,
And the baſe Cries of worldly intereſt,
None but a father's care can reaſon give:
For I'm too young and innocent to know
Trichs of diſſembling and forc'd piety.
Clairmont's a worthy man, I muſt confeſs,
And one, whoſe Love were too much honor for me;
Nor could I juſt exceptions ever find
Againſt his perſon; yet, to ſpeak the truth,
I never yet could find my ſelf inclin'd
To love his Perſon or his glorious Mind;
Eſteem as much as ever I could give,
He ſtill receiv'd from me as reverence due.
But whither art thou fled, my innocence?
I grow too knowing; can diſtinctions make
Beyond my Leſſons, 'twixt Eſteem and Love;
Do know their different Concords on the mind,
And can diſtinguiſh either's harmony.
For ſhame, Charlotte, be ſilent in thy fault:
Ha! I hope I have committed none as yet,
Nor do I think I ever ſhall▪
I love, 'tis true: but thouſand Deaths I'l die
Ere I betray my frailty to the Man,
For though my Love be Virtuous, yet ſo ſoon
To be o're-come will argue Eaſineſs;
Alas! why ſhould it though? muſt it be time
Should conquer more than ſympathy of mind?
Great god of Love, pitty a Virgins fate,
And if I muſt be wounded by thy hand,
Spare not the Inſtrument that caus'd my harm,
If he be wounded too I ſhall not mourn.
Lord! how I talk? but Womens hearts oppreſs'd,
Will breathe their ſecrets to the careleſs Air,
Rather than ſilence keep: Great god of Love,
Once more I beg that thou my Patron prove.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: O Lord, Sir! d'yee think I know not what I do?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Before heaven, I'l break thy head,
If thou but attempt it.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: That's a good one i'faith;
I know you do but try my Civility,
And whether I can be peremptory in good manners;
In fine, I am reſolute, and ſo much for that.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Well, and ſo much for that too.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Nay, now I am reſolv'd,
Nor ſhall thy Fate, O Rome—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Will ye, will ye, Sirrha?
Curſe on thy folly, it will be my ſhame.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: I'm ſure yours will be my ſhame,
Nay, a ſhame to our whole Family.
Not requite Obligations?
Ingratitude's a black Sin.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: But why in the open day?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Becauſe they ſhall know 'twas I did it.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: They'l take thee for a Fidler,
And think thou com'ſt to give them their welcome
To th' Town.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: P'heu! I'l warrant ye, why do I look
Like a Fidler? ha, ha, ha!—

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Here's your Siſters,
Ask 'em if if it were fit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What? am not I as wiſe as they?
Though they be of our counſel for the h • mming of your
Bands and Cuffs, I hope I know what belongs to
Gallantry (as they call't.)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Indeed you are a prime Gallant.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes faith, ask the Woman of the Tennis-Court elſe,
Who beat you for filching of her Balls to play
At Bouls on Holidays.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For Stew'd-prunes and Ginger-bread.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Out, Puſs—

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I think they'l tell you your own.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, what trim thing would he do now?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: S'death, he would carry the Fidlers to give
The Gentlemen that were at your window laſt night
A Serenade at Noon-day.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Cokes him, Pugg—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Baggages, I would ſo thrum your Jackets,
If it were not for my father,
I ſhould make you more mannerly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Away, Gull—

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Nay, nay, too much of one thing's good for nothing.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I will have Muſick for the Gentlemen,
As far as this can go; and that you ſhall ſee too,
And ſo be with ye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, pray ſtay, Sir, let him have his humor.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Pox on's humors, my Purſe will be the lighter
For his humors.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Not lighter than his head, I'l warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I find my father's conſideration in this buſineſs
Proceeds from the Purſe, more than from any folly
He conceives in the Action.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Truly, Siſter, I am much of your opinion.
But do'ſt think the Blades will come to viſit us to day?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'l warrant you; prethee let's in, we are not hal • in order to receive them.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: How careful are we in a trifling dreſs,
As if our clothes put ſtops unto the mind,
And fram'd the harmony of our Miſtreſs thoughts?

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.l: It argues cleanly curioſity,
A thing that draws the ſubtileſt Lady's eyes
To an attention of the perſon.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: But do'ſt thou like this dreſs?—
I am ſo little us'd to care how 'tis,
I know not when I'm well;
I us'd to take my Tailors word,
But now I am growing mighty ſcrupulous.
Prethee ſurvey me well,
How is my hair here; I'l wear no Cloak,
A Sword and Belt alone does better.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.l: A good ſhape ſtill thinks it warm.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: How can I chuſe when I am all on fire?
Oh! how I long to ſee my fair Charlotte!

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.l: But have you quite forgot your fair Bellmont?

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Thou know'ſt ſhe never would be kind;
Would'ſt have me doat for ever without hopes?
Beſide, I like her not ſo well as this.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.l: Yet if I might but freely ſpeak my thoughts—

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Prethee do.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.l: I think her beautiful as any one.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: I thought ſo too once,
But ſhe was coy, peſtilent coy.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.l: 'Tis true, there was ſomething in the wind,
More than I underſtood: ſhe would have hearken'd elſe.
Here comes her Brother, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Briſac, D'elpeche, Lamarch, Boute • eu, ſalute Clairmont ſeverally.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Have you been well quarter'd, Gentlemen?
It was my chiefeſt care you ſhould be ſo.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Extremely well, Sir, we humbly thank you.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Well, what news? how d'ye mean to paſs this Winter?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: We little hop'd to have had the happineſs,
That your fair preſence brings unto the place.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: What can there be more pleaſant to the mind,
Than ſharing mirth, with thoſe have ſh • 'd in danger?
We will be merry, Gentlemen, ſhall we not?
Are the Players goo • that are in Town?
Monſieur D'elpeche, you know, you are a Virtuoſo.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: They ſay themſelves they will do wonders for us,
I never ſaw 'em Act.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: I think the ſelf •• me Band was once at Orleans.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: The ſame, Sir, had the great miſchance.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: What was it, prethee?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Acting Orpheus deſcent into Hell,
Their Fire-works ſet a fire on the Stage,
Which burnt ſome part o'th' Town.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: The Town then ſhar'd in their misfortune.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Moſt certain, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: But, Colonel, what Ladies are in Town?
You are a neighbour born unto this place.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: But 'tis long ſince I have frequented it;
The fair Roſella I do hear is de • d,
Mar i'd to an old Miſer broke her heart with grief.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Was ſhe ſo handſome as her ſame did ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: When I was here laſt,
I did not ſtudy much what Beauty w •• ,
But yet, me-thought, I was much pleas'd to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: But don't you now obſerve with ſtricter eyes
A Lady's feature?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Troth, Sir, me-thinks I do begin;
Nay, I have ſeen a Lady in this Town
Not much unlike her.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Prethee who is't?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Sir, that were to diſcloſe my inclinations,
For I extremely like, and that's a kin to Love.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: And ſha'n't I be your confident?
I'l be very ſecret.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: When I begin to love indeed,
Perchance I then will tell you:
But yet the ſecret is not worth your hearing.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: I'l take your word till then.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: But may I dare to hope
You'l be as free with me?
For you of later years
Have much frequented Tours,
'Tis ſure for ſomething.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: I know not whether it be ſafe or no
To truſt young men, like you, with my Love ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Moſt ſafely, Sir.
A man like you needs never fear a Rival▪
Eſpecially of me.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: I ſhall be glad to hold you ſtill my friend.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: And I much honor'd in that Title, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Governor, your humbleſt Servant,
I hope you have excus'd my laſt nights trouble.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: You know not, Sir, with what great zeal
I ſtill ſhall court the honor of your preſence.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: I know your goodneſs, Sir, is infinite,
So is my will to ſhow how much I love you.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: I then need envy no man.
But will you pleaſe to ſee the Works this morning,
There are ſome things are lately finiſh'd
Do add much ſtrength to this fair place.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: With all my heart. Come, I'l go ſee the Works;
Theſe are the off-ſpring of a Soldiers Brain,
Which if they perfect prove, do ſerve to keep
And cheriſh him in's Age from preſſing foes;
They're children left to th' Pariſh to maintain,
And we the bold Pariſhioners muſt do it.

div.stage: Enter Beaupres, and Bellmont, Luyſon, Boy, as from • ravaling.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Let the Coach be led about by the B • idge,
VVee here c • n pa • s the River with a boat,
An land at the Garden do • e.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: VVe ſhall Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Now, fai • eſt Bellmont, is the Minute come,
In which your heav'nly charity m • ſt grant
All that I e're can wiſh for in this VVorld,
Or • ender me the moſt unh • ppy in it:
Oh ſpeak my Bellmont, are you ſo reſolv'd?

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: VVay Sir? do you think my mind ſo ſoon can alter?
You know I promiſ'd to fulfill your will.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: No certainly, I cannot fear that ill.
But fa • reſt, if your eras were ever Charm'd
With the harmonionss ſound of one ſweet • train,
Would you not wiſh to hear it play'd agen?
How willingly we hear of joyes are paſt?
But how much more of thoſe we are to taſt?
The Fryer will attend us in this walk;
I wonder he appears not yet,
The hour's paſt I did appoint our coming.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: But pray, Sit, give me leave to ask a queſtion:
And anſwer m • without diſſimulation.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: As to my Ghoſtly-father were I dying.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: I know there are not greater friends on earth▪
Than you, dear Sir, and my dear brother are;
Why do you not impart this buſineſs to him?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I'l tell you.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: Stay: do you think he doth ſuſpect nothing?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Truly I think he do's not.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: Pray Sir, then anſwer what I firſt did ask.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: That I am honoured with his kindeſt Love,
I really believe, And that's one reaſon why I'm ſilent to him.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: That now I do not underſtand.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: That he do's Love me, as I ſaid before,
I think moſt certain; ſo the reaſon is
Of all men's perfect love to one another
A great opinion they are belov'd too;
But did he know the paſſion I have for you,
He then might doubt my freindſhips perfectneſs,
And think it • oyn'd with ends upon
His goodneſs to me; and my love to you.
Bred but profeſſion of a love to him.
This, Time I judge coal I cure him off,
But yet, the doubt I know at firſt will breed
A coldneſs in him; and that coldneſs ſhake
Poor m • into ſuch Mortal apprehenſions,
As it would pitty you to ſee it.
That he believes I love you, I don't queſtion,
And ſhall do dayly more, when you are mine,
For I would have the knowledg grow upon him.
Beſides, ſince that wee firmly have reſolv'd that nought
Shall hinder the Uniting of our hearts,
Let's ſtrive to meet our bliſs the neareſt way;
And let dull Travelers purſue the Road.

sp.speaker: Bellem.
sp.l: If it be bliſs to make you maſter of
A thing I fear's not worth your ſo great joy,
Know, all that pleaſes you, brings ſuch content
Unto my mind, that I ſhall ſtudy ſtill,
Out of ſelf intereſt, how to pleaſe you moſt.
Here, Sir, can this hand by a proxy wed
It's heart to yours, for that was given firſt.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: And I moſt bleſt in this delivery:
But I will now be baſe as Tradſmen are,
Not truſt, without the bond be ſign'd, and ſeal'd:
'Tis all my wealth, of which I'm Covetous.
Here's one can draw it up forever ſure;
Welcome moſt honored Sir.

sp.speaker: Fr • er.
sp.l: All happineſs attend you Son,
And to this Lady what my prayers can gain.
I did not think you would be here before me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: We' • e making hafte unto our haven Sir,
And you'r the Pilot that we did attend.
I know fair Lady you'r acquainted with
The purpoſes that my Son did mention to me?

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: I hope a bluſh will be unneceſſary
In actions you allow.
Reverent Sir, I am,
An I crave your help as earneſtly as he.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Where mutual hearts expreſs the ſame conſent,
Heavens bleſſings give,
As to the proper Emblem of the Church,
And may all your's be doubl'd on your heads.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Thanks kindeſt father.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: Thanks moſt Reverent Sir.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Come, follo • me, where I will make you One,
Till dea • h do's cancel what you promiſe now:
And may you ſtill hereafter bleſs the minute.

div.stage: Enter Lamarch, Boutefeu, hanging about D'elpeche.

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.l: Come, come, prethee D'elpeche be not ſo nice,
I tell thee thou ſhalt chuſe,
And one will ſerve us both.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: On that condition, Gentlemen, I am for you.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Why, I'm content, I ſweat I'l break no covenants.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: Bouteſeu, have you your ſpeech ready?
You mention'd one laſt night.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Yes that I have, pox' do you think I cannot talk as ſinely as you, with your Metaphors and tricks?

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.l: Yes that a can, for all a looks ſo.
Well Mounſieur we ſhall hear what ſport you'l make,
For I am your Rival.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I but Mounſieur, I would ſcarce adviſe yo •
To make ſport with me before our Miſt • is:
D'ye mark that Sir?

sp.speaker: Lama • .
sp.l: Moſt lovingly I do intend to deal;
What ſhall we be? Ce • taurs, or Lapithes?
Quarrel about a Wench? no Pilades,
I thy Oreſtes will be ſtill thy friend,
And yet thy Rival in affection Bully.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.p:
Hey toſs, hard words, that I forbid in our bargain;
I'l ſnatch away the Wench, if you begin to talk ſo there; 'sdeath I ſhall be bought, and ſold, and not know what they mean; no, no, I'l have none of that, heer's D'elpeche can talk hard words enough for u's all.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: I 〈◊〉 , but I ſhan't ſteer your courſe,
I'l leave you to the ſtorms of loud Laughter.

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.p: Wee'l begin with you, ha, ha, ha, - ſee who'l fare beſt you or wee.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I, I, then let e'm laugh that winn;
Two againſt one is odds at foot-ball.

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.l: Oh I could bite thy lips off for that;
Nay, nay, the tyde comes in, for Wit begins to ſlow;
Knock, knock, D'elpeche, here is the houſe.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: Nay the door is open, enter Gentlemen, 'tis
My Lodging.

div.stage: And Enter again D'elpeche, leading Mariane, Lamarch and Bou • efeu, 〈◊〉 cibell.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: 'Tis too much honour Gentlemen;
And I'm too much acquainted with my ſelf,
Ever to hope that I can pleaſe you both.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: P'heu, never fear that, Lady:
If you will, I know you can do more than that do's come to.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: As how good Sir?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Nay, Souldiers never give an Explication of that they ſay or doe.

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.l: They may Sir, to their Miſtris,
Without the forfeit of their reputation.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: But what if they wo'n't Sir?

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.l: Then they may chuſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Moſt certain Sir, this Gentleman ſpeaks truth.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Why then I think yee both are anſwer'd;
But, Lady, as I was about to tell yee,
I love moſt paſſi • natly when I do begin.

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.l: And I began, the minute that I ſaw you.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: But that's foul play to end a ſpeech that I Began.

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.l: Why Sir? I have not made an end yet.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Prethee then do, and leave us to our ſelves,
O • go and help D'elpeche, he's out of breath.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: 'Tis then with laughing to ſee your fine diſpute.
Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, Siſter, Siſter, ware Guns, • 'are beſieg'd.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Look you to your own affairs, I'm well mann'd.
And can reſiſt the fierceſt ſtorm.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Well ſaid, you need fear no Attacks
As long as we are with you.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: Why, Sir, 'tis from you ſhe fears them moſt,
And from your friend;Lama. is kiſſing her hand. See, he has • ane in
Her hand already.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Troth now I think I'm even with him. Bout. kiſſes th'other.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: That thou 〈◊〉 , keep ſtill to that, Boy.
See, faireſt Miſtris, how happy thoſe men are
That venture boldly or,
And fear not the mortal Canon of a •• own.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But you more cunningly approach the Fort.
And hope to undermine it ere expected.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: Not I,Kiſſes her hand by this fair hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You might have ſpar'd the Oath, yet been bellev'd.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: No, I will rather ſwear again, than want credit.
By this fair hand,Again.▪ the Emblem of your mind,
I love you much, yet is my love as pure
As the white Snow this ſo reſembles.
You are too young and innocent to frame
A Rebel thought, were I made up of ill—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But, good Sir, ſwear no more, I will believe you,
And if you'r wiſe you will believe your ſelf.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: I will do any thing that you will have me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray then let's mark how they behave themſelve • .

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So have I ſeen a Dam'ſel 〈◊〉 to Church,
But by ſuch proper men I ne'r ſaw any,
Why, Gentlemen, 〈…〉 hand,
Pray let that go.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Not I, by 〈…〉 , Sir?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 , Gentlemen, 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: What does, Madam?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why my lip, a ſlie bit it 〈◊〉 now.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: That's but an excuſe.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Sir, may be I've a mind to blow my noſe.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I'l do't for you with my other hand.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Nay, rather, Madam, I will quit my hold.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: And I'l not be behind-hand in civility.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: I thank ye, Gentlemen, but you, Sir, firſt,
For you did ſhow the way.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Well, but I let go too.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: You did ſo, Sir, and I thank'd you too.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: Did you ever ſee ſuch Courtſhip?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not I truly, Sir; for pitty let's relieve her.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: Well, Gentlemen, how are yee with your fair Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Troth like beginners, how are you there?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Sure that very young Lady is not ſo brisk
In her Anſwers.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: We have beaten a Parly, or rather Truce
For ſome time, for we have left Parlying;
But faireſt Mariane, will you but bleſs
Our ears with one ſweet Ayr.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My Siſter, Sir, ſings much better.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay ſie, Siſter, now I muſt ſay
You ſhall ſing, you ſhould elſe have wanted
My intreaty; jeer me before company?
You know I never could, nor would ſing.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: I hope her authority and my prayers may be Succeſsful.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will not long be intreated,
For then you will expect much more
Than what you're like to hear from me.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Siſter, prethee ſing When Celadon gave up his heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No laughing, Gentlemen, I bar that before-hand,
Your pardons I'l beg afterwards.

lg.l: When Celadon gave up his heart
A Tribute to Aſtrea's eyes;
She ſmil'd to ſee ſo fair a prize,
Which beauty had obtained, more than Art:
But jealouſy did ſeemingly deſtroy
Her Chiefeſt comfort, and her Chiefeſt Joy.
Baſe Jealouſy, that ſtill doſt move
In oppoſition to all bliſs;
And teacheſt thoſe to do amiſs,
Who think by thee, they tokens give of Love:
But if a Lover ever will gain mee,
Let him love much, but fly all jealouſy.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: And I will be that Lover Lady;
For • proteſt I hate the vice extremely:
The fear of theeves is worfe than the loſs we can
Suſtain by them: w'ere ſtill a being rob'd.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Right Sir, As the Coward who fears death
Dyes ten thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Lamar.
sp.p: That Coward am I Lady, as often as I caſt mine Eyes upon your face, my heart's at my Mouth, and wants but your kind acceptance to be rid of me.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.p: Or you of it; for a Cowardly heart is not worth the keeping.

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.p: Sir, I may make bold with my ſelf, though I could wiſh you would not.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Fy, fy, Gentlemen, come give me your hands again, Siſter prethee one Song A la Ronde.

div.stage: They all Joyn hands and dance in a Ring, Anſwering all-together at the Chorus.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Amarillis told her Swain,
Amarillis told her Swain,
That in love ne ſhould be plain
And not think to deceive her.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Still he proteſted on his truth
That he would never leave her.

lg.l: If thou do'ſt keep thy vow quoth ſhe,
And that thou ne'r do'ſt leave me,
Ther's ne'r a Swain in all this plain
That ever ſhall come near thee

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: For Garlands and Embroider'd Scrips▪
For I do love thee dearly.

lg.l: But Colin if thou change thy Love,
But Colin if thou change thy Love,
A Tygreſs then I'l to thee prove
If e'r thou doſt come near me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Amarilis fear not that,
For I do Love thee dearly.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Fy, how I'm out of breath?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Faith ſo am I too, pray let's go in and take the Ayr of the garden.

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.l: Come Madam.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Nay Sir, take t'other hand, this was mine before.

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.l: Very good Sir, go D'elpeche we'l follow.
I would ſpeak with you, leave e'm.Pulls Bout: by the belt as he leads in Francibel.

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.p: How comes it Sir, that in a paſtime you dare do baſe injuries? does your brutality not let you know how you ſhould uſe your friends?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Brutality! ha! thou art a Brute to ſay ſo, draw.

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.l: This way a little, there we may be ſpy'd.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: God's my life here they are! how luckily too! and hard by our houſe!The Fidlers ſtrike up. Beats the Fidlers. play Gentlemen, play.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: What the Devil's this? ſome come to jeer us?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Why Gentlemen, what do yee mean?
Is this for my Civility?

sp.speaker: Lama.
sp.l: What Civility thou Aſſe? prethee begon, and quickly too.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: So I will, that I will, if you'l put up your Swords; why d'ye draw your Swords upon me? I'm ſure I meant no harm in't, but to make you merry.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: Why, how now, Gentlemen, what's the matter?
Swords drawn? fie, 'tis childiſh thus 'mongſt friends.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: O brave, here's our Gueſt, nay, now I care not,
He'l not ſee me wrong'd.
sp.p: VVhy, Sir, I came purely to requite the obligation ye all did my Siſters laſt night, and truly ſeeing them two, I thought you had been in the company too, and ſo I bad the Muſique play, but, Lord, had you ſeen how that tall Gentleman kick'd 'em, and how angry this ſame Gentleman was with me; why, pray, Captain, what hurt was there in this? I'm ſure I meant them no more hurt than my own ſoul.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: Go you home, the Gentlemen are much in drink,
But I'l appeaſe 'em for you, and we'l be all
Friends, and drink together.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Marry, I thought there was • omething in the matter.
Pox on their drink, they • righted 〈◊〉 Plaguily;
God b'you, noble Captain.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: Fie, Lamarch, are you not aſham'd, and
You, Boutefeu, Friends and Cam'rades to quarrel
For a Flie, a Nothing?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: A queſtion'd me with ſcurvy terms.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You us'd me ſcurvily, I'm ſure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Pox! I meant no harm in't,
And had ye ask't me civilly, I had told ye ſo.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.l: Away with your Punctilioes,
They're pretty things to uſe to others, but 'mongſt
Our ſelves, 'tis madneſs; come, let's ſee ye fight, O ye' are
Brave Fellows, why don't ye begin? the Montalto, the
Reverſo, the Stoccado, the hey, courage Blades.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Hang your ſelf, D'elpeche.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Before George, we'l trie theſe tricks upon thee, if thou be' •• not quiet, and two to one, you know, Boutefeu ſaid was odds.

sp.speaker: D'el.
sp.p: Come, ye two fools, I'l ha' this fool that was here just now, make you two Fools Friends.

div.stage: Enter Clairmont, Briſac, Charlotte, La-bar, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Madam, it is a ſin beyond a pardon,
But that your father eaſily cannot err,
In the opinion of the world,
To Cloiſter up a Beauty of ſuch worth,
Fitter for Courts and Princes to admire.
Is it not true, Briſac? Why art thou melancholy?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I cann't believe that he's of your opinion.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: What was it, Madam, that he ſaid?
For, Sir, my thoughts were bent ſo ſtrong,
They took away the ſenſe of all my hearing.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Why, I was blaming of her Father much
To bleſs this onely Town with his fair daughter,
And render all that's France beſides unhappy
In the privation of her faireſt preſence.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: I do not doubt ſhe'd be the faireſt light
In any Hemiſphere ſhe pleas'd to ſhine in,
But ſhe can find many Adorers here,
And not like Prophets, loſe her light at home.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: But Heav'n would have us all admire its work,
As all ſhould this the faireſt it e'r made.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Conſider then how many Hereticks
This glorious contemplation muſt needs make,
For many would ne'r think how Heav'n made her,
But think her Heav'n her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: I'm glad I can ſo aptly prove
A ſubject for your mirth or wit.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Madam, ſuch ſubjects as you are,
I muſt confeſs, do heighten wit,
For they do rarifie by pureſt flames
The dulleſt Lovers thoughts and heart.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Such ſubjects, Madam, make all ſubject to 'em.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: So, Gentlemen, how long can this ſtile laſt?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: As long as we find ſuch fair matter for't,
Which being Infinite in you, may prove Eternal.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Briſac, your Siſter.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Beaupres welcome, welcome dear Siſter.
Friend have you ſeen the General yet?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I ſhould be proud you would preſent me to him.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: One that begs the title of your Servant.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: I'm his, I do aſure you Sir;
For I'm acquainted with his worth already.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You honor me too much Sir.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Siſter, I'l make you happy,
In bringing you acquainted with a Lady,
In whoſe fair converſation all that's good
Is to be learn'd.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: A Loving Brother I have ever found you;
But in this moſt kind.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: To me his obligation is ſo great,
That I muſt ſtil remain his thankfull debter.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Labarr, how am I here confounded!
I cannot ſee 'em both together.
Your Servant Ladies; Gentlemen,Ex. Clair. I'm yours.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: What made him go away ſo ſoon?
He mention'd no ſuch haſte when he came hither.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: I gueſs the Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Peace dear Bellmont.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: What is it Siſter?

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.p: Some buſineſs with the Governor, what ſhould it be elſe?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I, I; but Madam, are you not extremely weary?

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: I never can, when I'm 〈◊〉 you Madam.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: You ſee the Siſter ſpeaks the B others thoughts.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: So fair a mouth as hers will ne'r want credit.
But come fair Siſter, let me call ye ſo;
Ye ſee how rude ambitious Love does make me,
Let me conduct you to refreſh your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Hem, Beaupres, hem, I'd ſpeak with you alone.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I'l return immediately.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I wiſh thou wouldſt to thy firſt nothing.
Thou'rt young and ſtout,
And if I can but fier thee—
Oh you'r welcome Sir, you brought the Lady I ſee.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: The Lady, Sir, I went for I have brought.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Yee have don well,
For people of his quality ought not
To ſtay a Minute for their Miſtriſſes.
You have made haſte, and uſ'd much diligence.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What Quality d'ye mean?
What Miſtriſſes?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Why, did not ſhe tel you who ſhe came to ſee?
But may be now her mind is altered;
For Women are moſt Fickle.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Malignii, ſure thou dream'ſt,
Or art diſtemper'd much with Wine;
VVhat is 〈◊〉 thou talk'ſt off?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: The fair Bellmont,
Clairmont's miſtris, ſhe whom Briſac ſent thee for.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Oh! is that the buſineſs?
VVhy I can aſſure you Clairmont was not thought off,
VVhen he deſir'd me to go.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Nor ſhe did not think to meet him here?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Certainly then you are not very intimate with her.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Not much, nor don't pretend to't.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Nay, Boutefeu told me ſo, ye have my Author:
But I was vext to ſee you ſent Ambaſſador,
And Ignorant of what was in the Commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: How came Boutefeu acquainted with this ſecret?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Phe • he know's more than that,
There's nothing that ſhe ever hideth from him.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: A Horſe, a fool!

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Does the VVorme bite?
Faith Sir, theſe horſe Fools ſomtimes do take a Lady
More than a ſpruce witty Courtier,
Every one of them have a humor.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: But I miſtake hers much, if hers be ſo.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I do not ſay it is—
I hope you don't think I had ſuch a meaning.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I ne'r interpret any man:
But what's your buſineſs with me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I'm coming to't;
I know you love my Colonel,
And out of that ſame knowledge I muſt tell
You, what does now moſt narroGwly concern him.
This ſickle General loves Charlotte too:
But let not your raſh youth attempt a thing,
In emulation of a friendſhip, not ſitting for you,
Then you take a work out of my hands
I have ambition too: I but crave your counſel.
S'death, a ſhall anſwer ſor't: Fool Bellmont,
And my dear Colonel, 'tis too much,
Nor ſhall that ſawcy fool, Boutefeu,
Dare more in this to do her right than I.
I think you love her, Brother, too ſo much,
You would not ſee another take his quarrel,
VVould ye?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Pray go on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why look you, thus I have contriv'd,
Boutefeu ſhall brave Clairmont at every turn,
VVho'l ne'r indure it.
Boutefeu is brave, you know, and th' other is
A powerful Enemy:
So theſe two fall by one another's hands,
And you and I may laugh at either's folly.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: The fame theſe things may breed unto Bellmont
Will certainly be great; but how good—

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Who's in fault?
Why deals ſhe with ſo many?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Peace, Bandog, 〈◊〉 ,Draws.
Or by Heaven I'l ſend thy Soul
To its own Manſion, Hell.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why what's the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I'l tell thee, Malignii, I ne'r could love thee,
Nor do I think I ever ſhall do much;
Thy converſation is moſt i • kſome to me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But you ſhall find how much unjuſt you are;
Here, kill me, why don't you thruſt?
I'l die the Ma • tyr unto Turth and Honor.

sp.speaker: Beau,
sp.l: How's that, thou Devil?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Since that my friendſhip to your hopeful youth
Has drawn me to this zealous folly,
I ought to ſuffer for't;
Hereafter you may live in ignorance:
And ſince you will not grant me for your friend,
At leaſt grant my intentions friendly were,
Or I dare draw my Sword to juſtifie 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: If they unfriendly were to fair Bellmont▪
They were unjuſt to all that is of honor.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hold, Beaupres; ſo may my Soul be bleſt
As I do honor her as much as you,
And this not fear, but truth exacteth from me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: God b'you, Sir,
I am ſorry thou couldſt talk me to ſuch paſſion.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: So, this is ſo plain,
There needeth no Perſpective-glaſs, I think,
To let me ſee that he does love Bellmont;
And though he ſeems ſuch Maſter of his Temper,
Yet if he be a man of fleſh and blood,
Theſe things muſt buz in's head;
And I'l take care Briſac ſhall underſtand
A buſſel which muſt needs defame his Siſter.
I care not if Clairmont or Boutefeu
Do periſh in his wildneſs, he muſt follow.
Like Ship-wrack'd men catch 〈◊〉 floating board
Another's faſten'd on, and ſhove him off;
So in the Tempeſt of deſpis'd Love,
We ſhove all Rivals to eternal loſs.
Then blame not perjury in ſuch a eaſe,
We may do all to gain a Rivals place.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Do you not wonder I have ſtole you thus
Unto a privacie, and diſturb'd your reſt?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: If there lie ought within my ſervice for you,
Reſt is unfit till I have done that duty.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Hey ho!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Why ſigh you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Ah, Siſter! pitty the Paſſion of almighty Love!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What means my deareſt Brother?
You do not ſpeak to me, your thoughts are
Some-where elſe.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: But I to you muſt utter all thoſe thoughts,
For you are onely fit to eaſe them now;
Would you do much, Bellmont, to eaſe your Brother?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: All that a Brother ever could expect
From one that does moſt dearly love him.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Siſter, I am undone,
My heart is conquer'd, and I know not well
What mercy to expect from her has won it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But how can I expreſs my ſervice in't?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Oh much, fair Siſter,
Very much you may:
She'l hear you ſpeak without an interruption,
And much ought to be ſaid
Where I do love ſo much.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I'l ſay all what you'l have me: but to whom?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: And can you well deſcribe my paſſion, Siſter?
For I would have the Copy that you draw
Come very near the ſad Original:
Paint forth each ſigh and doubtful groan I give,
The wound that every look imprin • eth here,
The mighty ſtorm is rais'd by groundleſs hope,
And the ſad ſhipwrack that deſpair will bring:
The mighty mercy 〈◊〉 a promis'd bliſs
Will make me ever happy, 'bove my merit,
And all this joyn'd with your ſweet Rhetorick,
(For Women will hear all that Women ſay)
Implore reward for one who, 'gainſt his will
Is now become a ſlave unto 〈…〉
Which is, you know, unjuſt, and yet I crave it,
And without which I die, reward had been
More due, if I'ad will'd the thraldome not foreſeen.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: Yet, Sir, I'm ignorant
Before what Judge I am to plead your Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: And I had quite forgot to tell ye,
Or may be I am grown ſo covetous of her,
That I am loath to give her name to th' air.
But, Siſter, can't you gueſs who 'tis I mean?
If that a born-blind man recover'd ſight,
And heard me tell him that the glorious Sun
Was th'onely object which ſhould dazzle him
Above all other,
He'd wink, and point unto that glittering Star.
And by approved reaſon ſay, 'Tis that:
Prethee, dear Siſter, gueſs.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: Is it not my new acquaintance, the fair Charlotte?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Oh 'tis! the faireſt that I ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Brother, relie on me,
If I do fail to do you ſervice,
It ſhall be want of power, not of will.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Thou beſt of Siſters! ever call me ſlave
To all thy Virtues, if thou do'ſt but this.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Sir, I dare promiſe nought, I'l do my beſt.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: So does the Merchant that in one rich fraight
Ventures his whole Eſtate, expect return,
Sails in his mind o'r waves as troubleſome
As his fair Ship doth in the greateſt ſtorm,
Which if it ſcape, returning richly home,
He fearleſs is of ſtorms in time to come.

div.head: ACT 3. SCENE 1.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: S'Death, I care not, I,
For him nor all his anger,
Let him be pleas'd again.
If that he be diſpleas'd without a cauſe.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: He ſays ye are a Horſe,
A thing unfit for human converſation,
And of ſo leud a Tongue,
No woman you once ſpoke to e'r could ſcape yee.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: But I dare venture, Sir, a thouſand Crowns
You'l hardly get him for to tell me this.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Not but he's ſtout enough, but 'twould diſpleaſe
The Colonel (to quarel here) and that he will not do;
He ſaid, he'd give the world for an occaſion.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: And that he ſhall not want:
Prethee, dear Major, tell him l'd ſee him with
His Sword in's hand.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Fie, Boutefeu, are you mad?
Will you thus lay your ſelf open to your Enemies?
He is the Colonel's neareſt friend;
And if I be ingag'd, whom will you have
To work your buſineſs for you?
Beſides, you'l find his coldneſs ſtraight,
And you may then occaſion find enough
To make him angry 'twill be much better
It ſhould come from him.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l:
Bu •
• ow? which way?
For I do long to chide his Boyisſh Cenſure.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Cla •• mont to night does give the Ball,
The Banket he has ſent to fair Charlotte
Y •• 'l • i • d him leading of Bellmont,
〈…〉 may put ſome • light upon him,
As taking her to dance out of his hand,
Or twenty other things, done, as 'twere, by chance,
Which he will never ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 ſuffer! S'death a ſhall,
And thank the doer too, that he may live.
〈…〉 you, mark but the end of this.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yes, I will mark it, Sir, moſt heedfully.
What a hot-brain'd fool is this?
He faſter runs to ruine than I'd have him;
〈◊〉 if he k • ll; Beaupres his ruine's ſure;
If nor, Beaupres moſt certainly kills him,
And then I think he'l hardly ſtay in Town.
Oh my dear brain, work, work more miſchief yet;
I have it—
I muſt needs render him ſuſpitious to
Briſac; but here is ſome more caution needful,
Raſhly to run between two ſuch ſworn friends
Is dangerous, nor is Briſac ſo ſottiſh,
To judge without ſome proof of a meant injury:
Nor muſt a find me tripping, if he do,
'Tis I muſt welcome then a double Foe.
But ere my hopes to ſad deſpair be hurl'd,
I'l open War declare 'gainſt all the world.

div.stage: Enter Bellmont, Charlotte as in a Garden.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But let me begto know your neareſt thoughts,
For friendſhip in all men grows up by truſt,
And ſure 'mongſt women it is much the ſame.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Begin to ſhow example in this kind,
For I do know your thoughts ſo noble are,
Th • t they are ſit to take example by,
And 〈…〉 be a Lea • ner.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Of me? 〈◊〉 , Siſter, now you do abuſe your friend.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Indeed I never mean it:
What ſhall we talk of? for I do believe
That all the world to us is ſo indifferent,
We ſhall like no diſcourſe but of our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I fear ſo too:
But I have a Brother that I muſt love,
〈◊〉 he deſerves it from me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Heigh: I have a Father too, but theſe are Kindred.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: 'Tis true: but come, I'l truſt ye with a ſtory.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: You will oblige me;
Beſides, I'l promiſe ſecre • ie.
And if in ought I ever can but ſerve you,
I ſhall eſteem my ſelf moſt happy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: That you ſhall judge when you have heard me out.
There is a man that's near related to me,
That loves the faireſt Virgin in the world,
His love began with the firſt ſight of her,
But has been ſeldom bleſt with that fair ſight,
And knowing too that he can ne'r deſerve her,
Loves much, hopes little, and dare never own't.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Alas! I pitty him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I wiſh you d • d.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Why can you think that any thing near you
Shall ever want my wiſhes for his good?
But pray ye on; Why can he ne'r deſerve her?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Not but their Qualities are very equal,
But ſhe is fair and good above the common.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Is he not virtuous too?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: He is believ'd of all to be ſo:
Nor would I pitty him, if I did doubt it,
But there be great oppoſers to his good.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: A brave good man needs never fear a Rival.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: His modeſty (a ſign where virtue dwells)
Perſwades him ſtill he is not good enough
To be belov'd by the fair Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: How? prethee, dear Siſter, leave me.
How ſeriouſly ſhe kept her countenance?
None to abuſe but your poor Servant thus?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Truſt me, I do not jeſt, Charlotte;
And did you know but half ſo much as I,
You would afford much pitty, if not Love.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Who e'r it be, h'as found a cunning Orator,
And one 'bove all the world that has moſt power with me:
But give me leave to ſpeak as freely to you,
And cenſure not my freedom as a guilt,
For I have ſuch a great opinion of ye,
That I durſt tell you all my Souls affections;
I do love, nay, love extremely,
And one that is nearly related to you;
One too, that never yet did ſpeak of Love,
Nor do I think he can mean any to me;
If it prove he, I ſhall moſt gladly hear you;
If not, then, dear Bellmont, I'l beg
You ne'r will ſpeak, to move my juſt refuſal,
For I can never love another man.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: 'Tis poor Briſac, may he e'r hope for mercy?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Pray hear me, for I do reſolve
To be moſt free and open with ye;
You are o'th'Sex, and equally concern'd
To keep all things within the ſacred Rule
Of Friendſhip, and of Maiden-modeſty.
You know it were unfit that men ſhould know
When we are eaſily conquer'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Leave that to my diſcretion:
But tell me firſt, is it Briſac?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: It is, O 'tis!
But may I take your word that he loves me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You may; nay, do not hide your face,
D' ye think I'l vent the freeneſs of your talk?
You ſhall ſee how diſcreetly I'l manage him;
For though he be my Brother,
Yet you're a Woman, and my deareſt friend.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Uſe me with care as e'r you hope for good,
And conſtrue not too hard my confeſs'd weakneſs;
Remember 'twas your Brother conquer'd me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Your freeneſs ſpeaks how innocent you are,
Far more than all tricks of a forc'd diſſembling.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I hope you will believe ſo, pray, Siſter, do.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Come, come, indeed I will.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Lord how ſhall I look? would I had not told you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Nay, why ſo? you are unkind in this,
He ſhall not know how much you have confeſs'd,
And yet I'l give him hopes enough to court yee.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: That's my good Wench.
Thou know'ſt I ever lov'd thee.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What would you have me tell you, 〈◊〉
I cannot, nor I will not feign a Lie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But 'tis impoſſible thou ſhould'ſt ſee nothing▪
How wert thou wont to find them?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What ends have you in this?
I thought when you came ſo p • ivately,
It was to uſe ſome of your former ſleights
For the undoing of a harmleſs Maid.
O you're a fine Gentleman, and kept your word well with 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Truſt me, I love thee dearly, Wench,
And that e'r long thou'lt find too;
But things are not yet as they ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What things? what ſhould be?
O the diſ • embling of you men!
When yee have once had your ends,
Ye care not a pin for us VVomen.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Fie, Luyſon, do not think ſo.
But prethee tell me, VVench,
Did they never ſend thee away on ſleevleſs errands?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Nor that I remember, but I have often left them
Alone together.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: That's my good Girl:
And did'ſt thou never find Letters?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: No • I indeed, Sir, why d'ye ask?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I have a reaſon for it,
VVhich much concerns thy good;
If thou canſt poſſibly, prethee ge • thy Lady
To walk here when 'tis late to night,
When that the B • ll is done, for coolneſs.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I'l do any thing you'l have me,
But pray be not you the cauſe that 〈…〉 ,
And remember what you ſo long have promis'd.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I will indeed, Luyſon, this kiſs, and farewell.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: I am glad I have met with you, for I was alone; have you ſeen Beaupres lately?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: No Sir: but I was ſeeking you.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Me Major? VVhat's thy buſineſs honeſt Malignii?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: My duty firſt of wayting on you, then a minde I had
To talk in privat wi' yee bout a buſ'neſs.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Though I am much unfit for buſ'neſs now,
Yet thee I'l hear • t any time.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Pray Sir, d'ye think I love you?

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: VVhy doſt thou queſtion it?
Indeed I do?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: And do'nt you know't hath been my chiefeſt care
To mind what does concern you and your good?

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: I ever had but juſt opinion of you.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Certainly then a Looker on may ſee
More at all games, than thoſe that are in play.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: When they do underſtand the game, they may.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Right:
Then freely let me tell you Sir, you'r wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Wrong'd? by whom?
Tis baſe to do it ſo, that I ſhould miſs the knowledge.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Thoſe that da • e do injuries to friends,
Dare nere ſuſpect that they ſhould underſtand it.
Beaupres 's your friend, he might have told you on't.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: By Heav'n I know he would, aſſoon as you,
Did he but once ſuſpect it.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Why Sir this heat to me?
I have never deſerv'd it from you.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Pardon me Malignii,
But wh • m you name my Friend,
And tax him with a want of care to me,
I • troubles me.
Pray to the buſineſs; for I know he know's it not.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: B • tter than any man.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Come you are miſtaken—
I know him better—
If you once ſuſpect his friendſhip to me,
I juſtly may ſuſpect all what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I ha' done Sir.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: How done? will you not tell me then
Where I am wrong'd?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: You will not hear me Sir.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Faith but I will: methinks it does concern me.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Know ye of no adreſſes made to your Siſter?

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Then they are conceal'd it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: It ſeems ſo; but if they honorable be,
Why ſhould I be concern'd?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: 'Twere fit you knew it though,
Women are things that may be over-come,
And need ſomtimes a Brothers Counſel.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Why then you do ſuſpect my Siſters Virtu?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Not I, by all that's good:
And yet I would not have her wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Nor ſhall ſhe be by the beſt he that Breaths.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Promiſe me then you will with ſtrickeſt Eye
Obſerve all things that may concern her,
You'l find who then is moſt your friend,
And who's the franker dealer with you, I,
Or thoſe that heedfully do blind your Eyes,
More at this time you ſhall not get from me:
But when your knowledg beginneth to be touch't,
You'l hearken to me better, and take Counſel.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: I'l do ſo now;
Good Major, tel me what thou knoweſt.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: By Heav'n not I:
And yet you ſha'not ſcape the knowledg.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: But 'twill be kindlier done, if't comes from thee.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Not I; why ſhould I venture for the name
Of making Enmity betwixt two men?
Yee are too great for me to come between,
And Joyning once again I'm cruſt to nothing.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Shall I receive no more injury mean time,
For want of this ſame Knowledg?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: No, I'l take care for that.
Farewell: Yet Colonel look about yee,
I ſay no more: When yee get a glimps
Come to me, I'l help your Sight ſomwhat further.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: What Devil is't he Ayms at?
This fellow is ſo Jealous in his nature,
All that he looks on is ſo magnyfi'd,
That what t'other's ſeems a Moat, to him
Appears a Mountain;
Beaupres elſe, as well as he could ſpy it.
