You are too great for me to come between;
Sure then 'tis no mean man do's Court my Siſter.
Ha! lairmont the General has often been
Aſſiduous in his viſits to her; and now Courts
The fair Charlotte; Curſe of all fools, 'tis he;
I, I, t'was he that Malignii did mean,
He Courts my Miſtriſs too, Why here's occaſion?
I'm glad of that yet; for I ne'r ſhall brook a Rivall.

Ye •
• re he durſt not wrong my Siſter.
For Frenchmen freely viſit whom they like
For Witt or Entertainment, without a Scandall.
Here ſhe is, I'l know the Worſt on't.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: Brother, you'r well met.
I ha' news for you.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: And Siſter I have ſome for you.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: For me dear brother? what is't?

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Nay, let me hear your's firſt,
Mine may be told at Leiſure.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: You know what you enjoyn'd me to,
I have been no ill Orator.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: How dear Bellmont? does ſhe know I love her,
And is ſhe not offended at that Knowledg?

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: Not much, I have appeaſed all;
You have free leave to viſit, and to talk:
But uſe this Liberty with much diſcretion,
I am ingag'd for 't.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: With the ſame Rreverence I would call
Upon a Patron Saint, I ſtill ſhall crave
Her goodneſs to me. But prethee tell me Siſter,
D'you think ſhe ever will Love me?
May be her friendſhip unto you
Has gain'd this bounty for me.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: There is ſome liking too of you:
You elſe had gon without it.
But you have got a powerfull Rival,
Not with her; but one who gaineth once the Fathers mind,
Boldly attacks the Daughter without Controul.
Therefore be you diſcreet.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: In that I will be govern'd ſtill by you;
But pray you tell me Siſter, is't not Clairmont
That you do mean?

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: Y • s Sir.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: I h've heard that he did once pretend to you.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: A galantry, nothing elſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: But Siſter make not ſo ſlight on't,
For 'tis much taken notice of.
And I dare force him ſtill to do you reaſon.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: Me? Alas I can claim none of him,
Nor would I, if I could.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: The man's not ſo inconſiderable Siſter.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: O B • other▪ let me beg, you'l take
Some other way to rid you of a Rival,
Make not me ſuffer all the effects of hate
For your great Love.
There's nothing I would wave to do you ſervice,
But this I beg, you • ere will mention more.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: So much averſion muſt needs ſpring from wrong.
I will nere force thee Siſter. Come let's in—

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Nay, pret hee weep not Chuck▪ I'l warrant thee there's no body will take the houſe off their hands, now we have left it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
But what an inhuman dog to turn us our juſt when theſe blades were come to Town? O the Tearing Cuſtomers
we ſhould have had

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: No matter, no matter, God's ſprecious they cannot hi • le • me my ſtanding on the King • ground, and we will vent our M • rchandize here in 〈◊〉 their Noſes; Set down the Table Chuck, there, there, ſo, lay the ſtools under it.
Po •• s let's be merry for all this Cl • ck.
Hang ſorrow. 〈◊〉 will kill a Cat.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Truly Husband I believe that's the reaſon ours dy'd this morning.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Away, Woman, away—

lg.l: When as King Peppin rul'd in France,
A King of wundrous Might,
He that could the Cor • nto dance,
Was straight wayes made a Knight.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: But why have you chang'd the Sign we had before? St. Lewis is as much reſpected in this Country.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I, but you know the Prodigal • child thruſt out of doors, kept Company with pigs (good wife) and ſows.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: • Tis true, and with hogs (good husband) and hogs.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Away thou Cock •• rice; peace here's company.
sp.stage: Enter Colignii, Delpeche, Mariane, Lamarch, Francibell.

lg.l: • leaſe you Mounſieurs Entertain
The Dam • iſels yee bring,
Here's • heer, I here nere was ſuch in Spain,
And Wine would Fox a King.
Here's Capons that from Bruges came
In p • ſt for expedition,
And Veal ſo white, that none in Gan •
C • n come in Competition.
Here's Sallet myſtick ſavour has
As myſtick as the colour,
A Lover being put to graſs,
Pick't it againſt Love's dolour.
Here's vin de Bon, vin de Champaing
And vin de Celeſtine,
And here is that they call Bouru,
VVhich to Loves Sports incline.

sp.p: Sa, Sa, Mounſieurs, what have you a mind to?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: Odd's my life, Gentlemen, here is the braveſt fellow I ever read of in all my Travels; Pray friend, what ſhow do you repreſent?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Show Sir?

sp.speaker: Coli.
sp.p: I, ſhow Sir, does that offend you? U'ds fiſh, I care not a fart an' you be offended at ſhow Sir.
What do you wear that in your hat for, Sir,
If it be not for a ſnow Sir, ha?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Why, for a Sign Sir.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: For a Sign? why are you the Poſt?
Ha, ha, ha, ha, a very good jeſt, did not I put a very good jeſt upon him Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Yes you did, a very good jeſt, ha, ha, ha, 'twas a very good jeſt ifaith Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: Why ſo it was Sir, for all your ſneering.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Why ſo I thought Sir, 'tis very ſtrange you will be ſo angry without cauſe.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: So, ſo, Gentlemen, my Brothers taken up.

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.p: I, I, let him alone, let's mark 'em.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: Why Sir without a c • uſe? I was angry at ſomething, I was angry at a poſt, and there you have it again, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I'm glad you are pleaſ'd again; for I find your Witts riding poſt, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: A pig, a pig, a pig, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: 'Tis the Sign of the Pig, and I'm the Maſter of the Cab • ret, which ſhall give you moſt Excellent content.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: Say'ſt thou ſo honeſt fellow? faith thou art a very merry honeſt fellow; Siſters, I'l treat you, and theſe Gentlemen, at this Cabaret he talks of; Prethee honeſt Friend where is this Cabaret? for I long to be in Cabaret.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Why here Sir, ſit down at this Table, And call for what you will.

sp.speaker: Delpe.
sp.p: How's this, how's this? S'death are you one of Urganda's Squiers? pray friend whence ſhall the meat, and wine come?

sp.speaker: Lamar.
sp.p: From Tripoli on a Broomſtick.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen, hinder me not the Cuſtom of the young gallant; Entreat but theſe Ladies to ſit down, and break my head If you be not well treated, I'l deſire no favour.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: Nor • o mony neither, I hope Sir.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Truly I won't; if you be not pleaſ'd above expectation, Ne'r Truſt one again of my profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Delpe.
sp.p: Faith Ladies this may prove worth our Curioſity; Come we will ſit down.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: What you pleaſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: That's my good Siſter; Co • e, come, La Couvert la Convert.

sp.speaker: Lamar.
sp.p: This begins to look like ſomthing, he's bravely ſtuft I'l warrant you, he is ſo well hung.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: Now Sir, a cold breſt of your delicate white Veal.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Here you have it Sir.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: Nay, nay, and a ſallet, good Sir, a ſallet.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Well Sir, I muſt untruſs a poynt.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: How Sir, to give us a ſallet? why have you been at graſs?

sp.speaker: Delpe.
sp.p: Why d'yee want a boyl'd ſallet Mounſieur?

sp.speaker: Lamar.
sp.p: Before St. Lewis an Excellent Trimming, I'l ha' my next Suit, that I go into the Campaign with, trimm'd all with Saſages.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: 'Twill make many a hungry Souldier aim at you.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: Well thought on ifaith Sir. Come friend, a Diſh of Saſages, a diſh of Saſages.

sp.speaker: Hoſt
sp.p: VVhy look you Sir, this Gentleman only miſtook the placing, theſe do better in a belt.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: A ſtrange fellow this.

sp.speaker: Delpe.
sp.p: I, is it not? come Sir, wine we ſee you have: Prethee let's taſt the beſt.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: That you ſhall Sir; If you'l hear Muſick, and a Song with't, I'm ready: you ſhall want no • hing here.
sp.l: Yee may Tipple, and Tipple, and • ipple all out,
Till yee baffle the Stars, and the Sun face about.

sp.speaker: Delpe.
sp.p: Away with your Drunken ſongs, have you nothing fi • ter to pleaſe the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Delpe.
sp.p: Come away with it then.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: Moſt Excellent iſaith! Here's to thee honeſt fellow with all my heart, nay ſtay a li • le, this is very good VVine: here's to thee again—heark you honeſt fellow, let me ſpeak with you aſide. D'ye Count here by pieces or d'ye treat by the head?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I'l treat by the head Sir, if you pleaſe; a Crown a head, and you ſhall have excellent cheer, VVine as much as you can drink.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: That's honeſtly ſaid; you know my father friend, tis Mounſier C • rtaux.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Yes Sir, the famous Scrivener here of Tours.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: VVell, 〈◊〉 us 〈◊〉 w • ll, I'l ſee thee pay'd.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I'l ſee my ſelf pay'd, I'l warrant you, before you and I 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p:
I 〈…〉 friend, but prethee ſpeak not a
〈…〉 then you quite diſgrace, Sir, your
〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: 〈…〉 wiſe is enough.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: 〈…〉 Friend where's the Capon of Bruges you 〈…〉 ?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Here at hand Sir, Wife undo my Helmet, this, Sir,
Is my Creſt.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: A very improper one for a marri'd man.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Yes faith and troth, he ſhould have had horns, ha, ha, ha,
Here's to yee noble Captain, a very good jeſt
As I am a Gentleman▪

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: I thank you Sir!

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Me think's you are melancholly, Sir!

sp.speaker: La'ma.
sp.l: Not I Sir, I can aſſure you: Lady's how
Like ye the ſport, an odd Collation, but well
Contriv'd.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The contrivance is all in all.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: What makes my Brother kneel, look, look Siſter.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Here's a health to our noble Colonel,
Gentlemen, ye ſee 'tis a good one!

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Yes, and a large one, but if both drink it
How ſhall we lead your Siſters home!

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: No matter, Hem: here 'tis Gentlemen, ſuper Naculum
Come, come a Tanſey Sirrah quickly.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Has pos'd ye there mine Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: That's as time ſhall try, look ye here Sir.
The lining of my Cap is good for ſomething.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: Faith this was unlook'd for.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: S'fiſh I think all his apparel is made of commendable
Stuff; has he not Ginger-bread-ſhoes on.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: No truly Sir: 'tis ſeldom call'd for in a Tavern,
But if ye call'd for a diſh of Pettitoes, 'twere
But plucking off my Wives Buskins.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: We'l rather believe then try.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: S'foot, I'le puzzel him now; a Chamber-pot,
Quickly Sirrah, a Chamber, O' O' O', quickly.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Here Sir, You ſee it ſerves for a good Cap with
Feathers in't. This won't do, do ye'r worſt:
Gallant I'l fit ye; call for what ye pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Nay I've no need on't, faith thou art a brave
Fellow: Here's mine Hoſt's health Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Could you procure theſe Ladies a diſh of Cream
Sir, this will ſhew your Maſter-piece!

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: 'Tis the only weapon I fight at; lo • k ye
Gentlemen the thunder has melted my ſword
In the ſcabbard, But 'tis good, taſte it.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Th'aſt my Verdict to be the wonder of Hoſts,
Shalt have a Patent for't if I have any
Power at Co • rt.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.p: This is excellent, Monſieur Colignii, I'l pledge You his health now.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: Why Sir, would you not have it otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.p: What if I would not, S • r?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: Then I would have made you, Sir.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l:
Nay now th'art down,
•• lignii falls he riſes ••• nk. prethee ſleep,
Or riſe and take the Hoſts Wife to dance.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.p: So I can Sir for all you!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Lord! how ſoon he got drunk!

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Why I told him he might drink as much as he Would, and ye ſee he has claw'd it.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.p: Prethee, honeſt friend, play us a Dance, Come faith, Ladies, let's be merry.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: As Crickets we, Come Siſter!

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l:
Some ſay the World is full of holes!
•• 'mar. ſings.
Play that friend.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I do, do (though the Tune and Song be very witty And old) the Dance is very pretty and new.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Truly I am very weary.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: We'l ſit and repoſe.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: O Lord, Siſter, you know the Ball is to night,
We muſt go home firſt, to adjouſt our ſelves.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l:
We'll wait on you Madam,
• hi • pers. Fellow.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I dare not, Sir, this Gentleman has commanded the Contrary.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Well come then Ladies, friend have you a care
Of him.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I ſhall Sir,
A moſt ſpecial care, I'l warrant ye. •
I'l firſt get him out of the way, to ſleep himſelf ſober.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: What would you have friend?
Prethee reach a pillow.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Troth you have pos'd me now Sir;
But i • you'l riſe, here 'tis; carry it your ſelf,
Come wee'l go ſleep in the ſhade,
Wife take up the Table and ſtools,
Come Ile help you.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Come, come a long boys,
Valiant and ſtrong boys—hoop hey boys.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: My Brother, Sir, is infinitely kind,
For I have done him ſervice.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: And be you infinitely careful too Bellmont,
For there be Tongues; moſt wicked Tongues.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: None that dare ever wrong my dear Beaupres,
And for my ſelf,
I ne're ſhall ſhame the owning of my Love.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I fear you do not underſtand me right,
And yet I am glad you do not too,
For Innocence, in what I mean, looks lovely,
And Ignorance here, more beauteous is then knowledge.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I am ſo far from knowing what you mean,
That I can't gueſs it, Sir,
For Heav'ns ſake tell me, what is't,
H • ve I offended? I will beg a pardon
Not for my will, but my unwilling fault.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I hope you need none:
But dear Bellmont be careful,
Remember who and whoſe you are;
Plague o' this Dog, how does he make me talk!
Nay, be not melancholly;
'Twas not of you I ſpoke,
But ſomething I have heard to day,
And of a Virgin too, ſo Innocent,
That after it I ne're ſhall think one Free
From ſlanderous Tongues.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yet I may hope to be the onely free;
Since I will ne're the leaſt occaſion give;
If it appear to all the World a Malice
'Twill be a foil to ſet my Vertues off,
Or rather yours; For all I have of good is ſo;
And may the Heavens ſtill make me fitter for you,
Or take my life, ere I unfitting grow
To coap with that fair worth and honour in you.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: O thou beſt of Women!
Make me not bluſh too much, becauſe
You did not underſtand my ſecret meaning
My thoughts were hurri'd and I angry grew
To think on mens blaſpheming Tongues
Againſt ſo fair an Innocence!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Who is it, Dear Beaupres, that is ſo wrong'd?
I will grow angry too; for w're concern'd
In all that's good and Vertuous to defend 'em,
It were as great a ſin
To leave a Cauſe, the gods ſhould undertake:
Nay, they at laſt will bleſs it, and us too
For ſiding with it.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſtill my pray'r:
But dear Bellmont, after the Ball is done;
Ile ſlip into the Garden, pray come to me:
From whence we may Contrive,
How I may get into your Chamber,
You will not ſcrupulous grow, to meet me now
At theſe late hours of night.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Indeed I ought to be moſt ſcrupulous;
Should any ſee't; the Cenſure they would give
(Not knowing what has paſt) my fame undone,
And what we after ſay, not be believ'd.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I can't blame your care:
But here it grow's too nice,
Will you not truſt me with your actions now?
I to my ſelf will anſwer all that happens.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You may command me any thing,
Ile do my duty and not fail to come.

sp.speaker: Clairm.
sp.l: But Madam, may I never hope,
By my aſſiduous and moſt humble ſervice
To gain an intereſt in your Inclination?
Tell me but what you'l have me be?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Your ſelf my Lord!
And think me as I am:
Too much below your leaſt conſideration.

sp.speaker: Clairm.
sp.l: 'Twere blaſphemy in any man to ſay ſo,
And much unkind in you it is:
But like to Notes, when as they neereſt are,
And not the ſame.
They ſound ſo differently, that one would think
Thoſe fartheſt, which with one ſmall turn,
Agree in all, and frame one harmony
Faireſt Charlotte, can nothing, nothing move ye▪

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Yes my Lord!
You do, to tell you freely all my thoughts:
For I do honour much your worthy perſon;
But when you talk of Love,
It is by me ſo little underſtood,
That all the explanation you ere give
Will n • ver make me knowing in the Language.

sp.speaker: Clairm.
sp.l: Will you then give me leave
To try your Father, he can better ſpeak,
And having ſpoken be better underſtood,
By one who is his Daughter, and obedient,
I can't diſlike this Maiden Back-wardnes
Loath to beſtow your ſelf, without his knowledge.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: That I eſteem you honourable,
My Lord you now ſhall ſee; ſince I dare beg
A Boon; and a ſtrong Boon it is to beg
You being young (and as you ſay) moſt loving,
Call then thoſe vertu's to your aid
That you are Maſter of,
And I conjure you by them all,
That you ne're preſs my Father in this buſineſs,
You may command a thouſand hearts,
Do not then plunder mine.
Or make uſe of Authority to force it;
'Twill not be worth your owning if you do,
For 'twill be broke, moſt miſerably broke.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Then 'tis Averſion, not a Maidens bluſh,
That makes you thus deny me!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Indeed you are too blame to call it ſo,
I know you would not have me lie
And pay your real with one that's feign'd,
My Friendſhip and my beſt reſpects
You ever ſhall command,

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: It was unjuſt to cauſe me to love ſo much
When I want wherewithall to make you kind!
But promiſe to be juſt in this,
Endeavour but as much as ere you can,
(Since you wi • l have it ſo)
To love you leſs.
Thus you going forward, and I going back,
Perchance at laſt we may much nearer grow
For did I let mine be as now it is
The Flame of all the world could ner'e arrive
To ſuch a Height,
And I the lighted Beacon
A Torrent unto ruine, blaze alone.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Tis I, my Lord, that muſt complain of Fate
That ſee ſuch Vertues in a mind?
So rich a preſent as a heart like yours
And have not one, wherewith to pay the bearer.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: And muſt I ſuffer all this Torment too
That you would gratefull be, yet ſay you can't!
O ye Gods, forbid Charlot to fro vn upon my action,
And I will ſend ten Thouſand Rivalls to ye
Were they made up in one;
For they muſt ſure be bleſſed that can gain
Th' affections of ſo fair a Virgin here!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The Gods are juſter, Sir, then to permit
You ſhould do harm to what did never wrong ye
He ne • 'e laid claim to what you cou'd call yours.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: B • t he ha's rob'd me of my ſouls delight
Such Treaſure as the world compar'd to it
Would fall ſo ſhort of all compariſon,
As none but fools would ever offer at it
And yet I cannot blame him,
To make ſo fair a prize of this
Who would not Pyrate turn, 'gainſt man and heaven?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: O fy! my Lord!
Spare heaven, who can revenge it's wrongs.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Th' • ve tan'e you from me, Puniſhment too great
For all I hope I ever ſhall commit.
But Madam ſha'nt I know
The happy object of your Care?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: When I do find you better temper'd
Ile tell you, and I hope you'l love him too

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Ile ſtudy ſti • l to pleaſe you if I can.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: My Lord! Here comes Company.

div.stage: Enter D'elpech,TOWN. leading Mariane, La' March Francibell, to them Boutefe • .

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I fear we are too late,
'Twill be uncivill if they have begun.

sp.speaker: Delp.
sp.l: No, no, Ile warrant you.
Boutefeu • , how doſt man?
Thou haſt loſt the beſt Comedy:

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I care not, I.

sp.speaker: La' Ma.
sp.l: Here Sir, handy dandy, which hand will you have
For I ſee your Worſhip's in a ſcurvey humour!
Why what a Devil ayl'ſt thou man?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Prethee, La March, let me alone,
I am ſerious at preſent.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I fear the humour is not All a Mode at Balls, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: No more is the dreſs of your head, Madam.

sp.speaker: La' Ma.
sp.l: Prethee be not ſo Clowniſh,
Thou wert ſuch a pretty fellow, hadſt but a little breeding?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Reſt ye merry Sir, I have other fiſh to fry.—

sp.speaker: Delp.
sp.l: What the Devil ayles he?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Troubl'd with the Botts, Ile warrant ye.

sp.speaker: La' Ma.
sp.l: The worme bites; come Ladies here's the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Nay Sir, we might hear this Houſe by the Muſick.

div.head: ACT 4.
SCENE 1.
div.stage: Enter Clairmont,The new Scene of the HALL. Charlot, Beaupres, Bellmont, Briſac, D'orvile, D'elpeche, Mariane, La'march, Francibel, Boutefeu • , Attendants.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: GAllants and Ladies take your ſeats.
Begin Muſick.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Madam,Begin the • lows a little. methinks this is too grave,
We are amongſt our ſelves,
And are not ti'd to this ſame Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I am glad you are of that opinion Sir.
I much more like ſome lighter Dances.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: I, I, Beaupres can lead you many.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: But why will not you dance, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Truly I ſeldom do, Pray excuſe me, Sir,
I'l ſit and entertaia the Governour.

sp.speaker: Chair.
sp.l: What you pleaſe,
Come, Monſieur Beaupres, pleaſe you begin.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Moſt willingly, Sir.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Moſt excellent I'ſaith, come, come, give not over ſo,
Some ſingle Dance, any thing to be doing.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Nay Sir, pray let them begin for I am out of wind.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Madam, you here are Miſtreſs!

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l:
Come Madam!
• outefeu takes
• ellm, out of
• eaup. hand. •• rikes him, and •• ps to his word and 〈◊〉 . I think you are
We • ry Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Uncivil Villain, take that

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: S'death unhand me, Gentlemen, O the Dog—

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Away Churle! ſuch inſolence before my face

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Fie Gentlemen! th • s to diſt • rb our mirth!

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Fly Gentlemen, fly! O, if you had ſeen
That tall Fellow how he thwacks Fidlers, you would
Fly with expedition; have ye a mind to have your Fidles
Broke about your Pates?

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.l: Not we! we thank ye

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Hang lag, hang lag:

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Colonel, ſecure your friend:
Come Sir, do you not ſtir from me,
Have I your Paroll you will not.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: 'Tis hard! but ſince I ſhall be worſe confin'd,
Yes, Sir, I give it you.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Come! lets in, the Ladies all are • led in feat!

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, here's one ſtill.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Siſter! what made you ſtay! you might have gain'd
Some miſchief!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I was afraid to ſee you 'mongſt their ſwords
But durſt not leave you:
I hope you are not hurt, Sir:

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: With nothing but his moſt uncivil uſage.

div.stage: Enter Malignii, as in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Malig,
sp.l: So, ſo, this does begin to work:
And I have watch'd the iſſue with ſuch heed,
As wealthy Fathers that expect an heir
From their lov'd Wives to own their fair poſſeſſion.
I'm ſorry they were hindred from the miſchief
That this might have produc'd.
But time will ripen all; and quickly too,
For Boutefeu will ne're ſleep unreveng'd,
And t'ther hates him too beyond the common.
So that, they'l find out ways to act my wiſhes:
Now, Love, if ever thou didſt Rhetorick teach,
Learn me a language of that moving force
That I may touch the faireſt Bellmonts heart:
I wonder ſhe appears not, for that Wench
I know will work her to this evening walk,
Minutes do ſeem Gyants as they run;
But will ſeem skipping Dwarfs when ſhe is come.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: Why doſt thou ſhake ſo, Wench?
Thanks to heaven, there is no hurt done.

sp.speaker: Luii.
sp.l: I but, Madam, I was ſo frighted.
I cannot hold one joynt ſtill,
Pray, Madam, give me leave to go to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: I prethee do, I dare be here alone:
I know, if he can get from my Brother, he will come!

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: O, there ſhe is,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Who's there? Speak!

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: The humbleſt of your ſervants, Madam!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Malignii, what makes you here ſo late?
Is my brother in the Garden?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Not that I know of, Madam,
But I came to talk with you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: With me? 'bout what?
I'l but call my woman: Luiiſon▪

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: You need not, Madam, ſtrait I'l do't for you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Pray good Major, what's your buſineſs with me?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Cannot you gueſs? or have you quite fo • got
The humble offers I have long ſince made you
Of the moſt pure and faithfulleſt affection,
That man e're bore to woman?
The ſuit is ſtill the ſame, and I am ſtill
The miſerable ſame Petitioner,
'Tis bootleſs now, I think, for to repeat
Things I have ſworn ſo often to your ears
(For there they ſtopt) and never could get further▪
I need not ſwear how much I am in love.
Since all that ſee you die of the ſame paſſion,
Nor need I tell how faithful I will pr • ve,
Since thoſe fair Charms where my ſoul is • etter'd
Can ne're be broke by any rebel heart.
What ſhould I tell you then? nothing,
'Tis not my Que to tell you what I am▪
But humbly here to beg what you ſhould be,
If not for mine, at leaſt for pity's ſake:
Sure mercy dwels in you: for 'tis in heaven.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: How often have I told you, Malignii,
That it was much unfit for me to hear
Diſcourſes of this Nature?
Why o'ye trouble me and your ſelf too?
A reaſonble man would have been anſwer'd.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: But reaſon never yet with Love did cope.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Becauſe you want it, o'ye think that I
Muſt bar my ſelf the uſe on't?
'Tis late, and I blame-worthy, here to hold diſcourſe
With men alone, Good night, Major:

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Stay, Madam, for I've much to ſay,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: To morrow will be fitter for to hear it.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: No time ſo fit as now:
Nay, Madam, you muſt not go as yet!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What rudeneſs d'ye practiſe?
Do you know who I am, and where?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Yes Madam, very well:
But I am now reſolv'd I will be anſwer'd
In ſomethings, then trouble you no more.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What means he? Heave'n!
What is it, Sir, you would be anſwer'd in?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Is it impoſſible you e're can love me,
If I ſhould work my honour and my name
To ſuch a pitch, as they might make you greater,
Give me at leaſt that hope;
For Lovers think that all is poſſible,
Pray Anſwer, Could you love me then?

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: Yes, very much:
For I extreamly Love a growing Vertue
That ſhoots men up to Honour and Renown,
But yet my Love will never tend that way
That leads to the uniting you and I.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Why, is my perſon then ſo odious?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I ner'e examin'd that;
But may be 'tis impoſſible
There be ſome other reaſons.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: And is this all the hope you'l ever give me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: All that you ever muſt expect from me.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Then Love direct me:
For I will not dye for want of what I now can take.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Help, help—Murther

sp.speaker: Malig
sp.l: N •• , you'r out of hearing,
This way, or Ile dr • g ye.

sp.speaker: Luyſ.
sp.l: within. Madam, Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 and the Furies ſtop thy throat:
The Houſe will riſe

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: O Wench, I have been frighted out of my wits,
That Villain, that damn'd Villain.

sp.speaker: Luyſ.
sp.l: What Villain, Madam? who was here?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: —Maligni. The Monſter of all Villany.
He would have raviſh'd me.

sp.speaker: Luyſ.
sp.l: The Gods forbid:
When your Brother hears on' • .
He'll • u • ely kill him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Tis true, therefore be ſure you never ſpeak on't more,
I too much miſchief fear from what to night
• as hapen'd, come away.
I ne're again will walk ſo late alone

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: •• me glad of that yet
• or 'twas all my • ear:
O this damn'd fooliſh Wench to cry ſo loud.
The houſe is up, I hear e'm.

div.stage: Enter two or three Servants, with lights and Swords.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Stand! who goes there? what are ye?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: O Major, here was ſuch a noyſe juſt now

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I heard it too▪ come let's ſeek about.

div.stage: Enter Briſac half unready, Servant with a light.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I know not, Sir, I heard your Siſters voyce!

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: What is the buſineſs, Major?
Saw you my Siſter?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Not I, Sir, where is Beaupres?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: I left him in my Chamber:

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Are you ſure on't?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: I, I, why doſt ask?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Nay, for nothing if you left him there,
You may to bed again, I have been round the Garden.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Ile firſt to my ſiſters Chamber

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: And ile not ſtay—
Her mind may alter,
To morrow I ſhall learn all from Luyſon:
Plag • e had he been parted from Beaupres,
I could at • worſt have put it all on him
And ſwore her down, That I had parted them.
And ſhe for a pretext had then cry'd out

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Nothing Siſter, why did you cry out?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Why, I was walking, Sir, to take the ayre,
And ſaw a man, that ſomewhat frighted me,

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: You did ill to cauſe this ſtir for that.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Women are frightful, Sir, by night;

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: To bed, dear Siſter, all the Houſe will riſe
Come friend, to night you needs muſt lye with 〈◊〉 ,

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I ſhall be too much troubleſom, I fear.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: I know your meaning,
Nay, ile not hinder you;
But take my Counſel in the place and time,
What Devil made him offer it to you▪
And to my Siſter too,
Had you two ever any words before?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Not I the leaſt.
Nor can I gueſs the meaning?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: He was put on, I lay my life;
Me-thoughts Clairmont did take much care of him:

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I did not mind any thing of that.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: I know ſomething more then you think,
Which I will have account for;
Beſides he is my Rival.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You alſo know I love you, Sir,
Seek not a quarrel on a groundleſs ſcore:
'Twill be thought ill: however you do fare in • t
If he has wrong'd you ever; Ile not ſpeak
One word to hinder what your honour calls for▪

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: H'as affronted one thats very neer me,
And I will reaſon have for what is done.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I had an Item given me too of that:
But thoſe that did it were miſtaken, Sir,
For too my knowledge, he could never wrong her.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: H'durſt not that—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I do believe ſo too—

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: How comes Boutefu ſo ſawoy grown
Before him, and me too? There's ſomething in' • :

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: There is ſo—
But I would not willingly Miſtake!

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Nor I; The morning ſhall declare the doubt,
Or I wear that can find the riddle out.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: I knew the Fool had ſomething in his head,
〈◊〉 was ſo ſullen grown o'th ſudden.

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: But why he pitch upon Beaupres?
H'as ſeen him often on occaſion too,
Where he hath behav'd himſelf with honour.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: T • ou! That's not it:
Though he be young, he 's known a man of worth,

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: H' ſerv'd me almoſt the ſame trick.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: But I think there's ſcarce that freedom
T'wixt to' • her and him!

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: 'Twas ill and fooliſh in him—
O Major, how is't w'y?
You have hardly been ſeen of late.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: You'r happy men! nothing to do,
Court Ladies, and be fine.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Indeed your buſineſs now is great,
In Winter Quarters there's much ſtirring always.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: They are not yet well ſettl'd, Sir,
When they are, you ſhall ſee me
Frisk and dance, none ſo merry?
But what was the Matter laſt night, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: D'elph.
sp.l: 'Tis true, you were not there!
Why, Boutefeu affronted the Colonels friend Beaupre.
And had a knock for' • .

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Is that all! reſt them merry blades,
Thoſe that ſeek work will find ſome always ready.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: But I am ſorry, 't lighted mongſt our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: So am I too, but who can help it?
Ile be hang'd if Boutefeu did not hate him
For wearing ſtarch in's Boot-hoſe Tops,

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: Like enough:
The gentleman is wondrous moody?

sp.speaker: D'elph.
sp.l: No, no, he would have forborn there
There was ſomething ſtuck cloſer then that.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: If you knew him aſwell as I,
You would hardly attribute ſo much deſign to him.

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: I dare ſay he never had any in's life!

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Come, Gentlemen, 'tis early, where ſhall we walk?

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Any where: Let's ride about the works.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: 'Tis done; The air will do us good,
Come, La' March, you had rather go viſit
Your Suttlers Wife, I know.—

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: I cannot hinder any Gentleman,
But, if I might perſwade you, Sir,
You ſhould not quit Employment for ſuch trilles.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: 'Tis done! nor will I ſerve
Under the man that broods him ſo.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: You know, Sir, Beaupres is a man of courage
He needs not that: Beſides ile tell you freely,
The injury was great that you did offer.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I had ſome reaſon for't (my Lord)
You may believe! I am not elſe ſo Brutal.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Good Captain, tell it me—

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Good morning to your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Good morrow, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Did you receive the paper that I ſent you.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: I did, Sir, and you are moſt free!

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I thank you, Sir; my Lord I kiſs your hand.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Stay; nay I can here confine you for ſome time;
Though of Command you have diſcharg'd your ſelf!

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: If it be'nt long I ſhall be moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You need not take ſuch care, aſide Boutefeu:
I ſhall find time to anſwer you.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I take your word.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Mounfieur Briſac! I would fain ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: And I did hither come to the ſame purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Pray anſwer clearly to what I ſhall ask.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip need not queſtion that.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Do you pretend to the fair Charlot?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: I love her, Sir! if you call that pretending.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: And do you know ſhe is my Miſtreſs, Sir?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: That lies in her diſpoſal—
But I do know that you make Love to her.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: But come, my Lord, I muſt examine too,
Did you ever pretend unto my Siſter?

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: May be I did?
I am not bound to ſatisfie demands.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: And do you think to raiſe that Siege,
And lay it to my Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Colonel, let's uſe few words!
I find we are agreed in what we mean!

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: How ſhall we get to be alone!
If theſe two leave us, ſtill the thing's the ſame!
I know they will be doing.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: The place is here moſt fit, for none can ſee us,
And I am pleas'd with my friend,
If you are ſo, there needs no farther Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Yes, pray my Lord, 'tis for a Miſtreſs that we ſight,
We'll do it decently,
Not like the rage that choler works men to.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: I know by this you underſtand.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Be careful friend of what I love, your ſelf!
And where we'r both, the world can never win us!
Monſieur Boutefeu! ſee Sir, occaſion's offer'd.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: And you may ſee, Sir, I was buſie ere you ſpake.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: Blind P • ſſion is the mad-mans ſate.
Who ſtrives to conquer Love, by ſhewing hate,
Come, Sir.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: How he drils me—
So cunning at your Weapon, Sir?
There 'tis I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: They will have done before me,
Stir not, or I will nail thee to the earth,
How is it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Well: prethee, look to him
I fear he's worſe.

sp.speaker: Clair.
sp.l: This care is noble in thee, brave Briſac,
But comes too late;
Heav'n forgive me, I do freely thee, farewell.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: What damn'd luck have I?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Thou art not 〈◊〉 I hope▪

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Indeed I am.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Where dear B • aupres.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: In every drop that falls from you
My ſoul does drop a Tear.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Away with grief, 'tis womaniſh,
Lead me to the houſe, but ſay you found me ſo;
Relate not you were with me in the bus'neſs,
There is much danger now that he is dead.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: And would you have me leave you ſingle
In any danger?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: What will your ill avail me?
You being free you will be abler far
To do me good▪

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Out of that hope I will obey you, Sir.

div.stage: Hoſt and Coligni having ſtood behind and ſeen all that paſt.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Here's fine work,
This is your fault, I would have rais'd the people.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Why, I did think they had been in drink,
To'ther day I'm ſure I was drawn upon
By men in drink, but they did no hurr,
Only kick'd ſome Fidlers, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: You told me
You knew they were in jeſt;
Here's fine jeſting marry,
Nay, he's gone, cold as earth.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Why, let him go, 'twas none of our faults,
H'might ha' look'd better to himſelf,

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Alack poor Gentleman,
Who were the other three that went away?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: I ſaw no body; I,
Are you mad? will you ſay you ſaw any body,
And make your ſelf a party?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Why will that make me a party,
Ha' you Law for what you ſay?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Yes, marry have I!

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Why, I'l ſay I have ſeen no body this two days then.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: I, I, do!
So, ſo, then he can never recover the reckoning of me:

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: But who ſhall we ſay hurt him?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Why, ſay he hurt himſelf upon Chance Medley.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Well, do you look to't; I'l ſay what you bid me.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Then be ſure you ſay, you ſee him hurt himſelf!

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: We had better be gone and ſay nothing!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Who are ye?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: We? why, we are men as you are!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: How long have you been here?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Not very long.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Yes, but we have! what then?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Were you by when this Lord fell?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: We were by when he hurt himſelf
With Chance-medly!

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Honeſt friends, this fellow lies:
We came juſt when he had hurt himſelf!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: How's this? how's this?
Come, come away with them, here's backwards and forwards;
The Governour will have the truth out on ye,
I'l warrant ye;
Come, help Sirra to lift the body.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Hold, hold, Bellmont, 'tis now my part
To lay the Treaſure out of all my Tears,
'Twas not your Rhetorick, but 'twas he that gain'd
The full poſſeſſion of the heart you ſpoke for,
And I will drown this houſe in ſuch a floud
Shall ſpeak my paſſion, and how much I lov'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: O, envy not my eyes this mournful • aſe▪
Who elſe would burſt; Poor Brother.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: O my Briſac, if thou ſhouldſt leave me now,
How ſhould I wander in the dark of Love?
No Ghoſt without a Tomb ſo miſerable.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Whilſt there be hopes
Why ſhould we 〈…〉 ,
And throw Our ſelves 〈◊〉 his ſea of grief,
Before the Veſſel's ſ •• k, our hopes are ſtor'd in.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 heart • little, for I would not be
Incon •• ant in my dying,
I'de live to love him, •• ill he did leave me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I hope your Lo ••• may laſting prove,
And interchang'd 〈◊〉 ſo here,
And that this il-look'd 〈◊〉 is but a Scene
To repreſent what you at laſt muſt • uffer,
He or you, leaving th'other here behind,

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Heav'ns take me firſt, then order me to guard
Him from all ill.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Come! dear Charlot,
Let us enquire with haſte
The Oracle of our enſuing fate
Which by this time the Surgeon here can give us.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Propitious be, O Heaven!—

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: So is our Colonel too,
I fear he'l follow.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: The heavens forbid:
Yet if he ſcape his hurts
I doubt it may go hard with him at Court,
Knowing th' others greatneſs!

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: I hope not,
His Services may ſomething plead for him
Beſides we hence can make his way
To ſome ſecurer place (having more health)
Till he ha's got his pardon from the King.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: I would do any thing to ſerve him,
Come lets go ſee how things are?—

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: There walk you two there, till the Governour comes,

Come Gentlemen, weel lock' •
〈◊〉 — Exit Guard.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: So now we are in a ſine pickle,
This comes of your Chance-Medly,
A Medler cloſe thy chops when thou 'rt dying,
Indeed, Squire, I mean that they call a Medler,
Is this your Law!
I could hav • found out a better
Trick of Law my ſelf then this.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Prethee! what a ſimple fellow this is,
What trick of the Law could you have found out?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Why, run away, when we firſt ſaw what came on't
For he that runs away, they ſay, ha's the Law on his • ide!

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Why, who the Devil would ere have ſuſpected,
That they ſhould take two civil men Priſoners.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: You ſaid juſt now that I was a ſimple man,
But Ile be judg'd by all this Company,
Who is the ſimpler fellow, you, or I.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Ile not enter into the Liſt of Compariſons
with any below my own rank:

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I muſt be a rank fo • l then—
But pray heark ye me, what muſt I ſay?
For I ſhall be d • ſh'd and baſh'd at the Governours queſtion,
For all he's an Aſs, yet he has ſome pretty conceits
As they call it in the L • w.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Why, mark me well;
We are no • ſuſpected to have done the thing our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I think not!
No, why ſhould they?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: He that ſuſpects wrongfully doth himſelf wrong,
For ſlander ſly's back in the ſl • nderers face.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: True, like a man that piſſeth againſt the Wind.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Why, then all that we ſhall be ask'd is, who we ſaw th • re?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Very good, Sir, and you ſay you don't know.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Prethee peace! I never heard ſuch a haſty fool.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Why, I onely te • l you, what I will ſay my ſelf!

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Why, look ye; there you make your ſelf a party again,
They •• think you but diſſemble and wo'nt tell.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Why, what ſhall I ſay then?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Why, name any body, and then let them clear themſelves
As well as they can,

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Pray tell me who you'l name; for we muſt not name
The 〈◊〉 man▪ you muſt name one and I another.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: O no, no, we muſt both name the ſame men,
Or elſe they'l catch us tripping.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I, the ſame men we muſt agree on,
But you ſhall name one (as I ſaid) and I another.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Why, I'le name Monſieur D'elpeche our Gueſt,
Becauſe he pawn'd me for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Squire, 'twas your own fault.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: I, I, but he might have choſe whether he would or no,
But who will you name?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Marry e'en Monſieur La Rock,
That put me out of my Tenement, I thank him.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: He's a cunning Fellow:
But no matter, Jacta eſt Alea—
Said Caeſar when he leap'd a Ditch.

div.stage:
Enter D'orville,
〈◊〉 Hearſe 〈◊〉 out on a • able. Attendants, La Barr.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: This Object is ſo cruel that it calls
Tears from a Souldiers Eyes;
No Scythian but would weep
To ſee ſo fair a Worth nipp'd in the Bud.

sp.speaker: La Barr.
sp.l: H' was my noble Patron, yet my grief
Suffers encreaſe, becauſe I was not with him:
I might have hindred this, or faln too.
But pray, Sir, let's learn the perfect truth.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: We will endeavour it.
Monſieur D'elpech you're welcome;
And you, brave Captain; ſee your General's kill'd,
And your poor Colonel mortally wounded.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: It grieves us much:
How came this Accident?

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: We cannot tell;
But D • ath did n'ere
Play for a fairer prize and win both ſlakes.
Here's two can give account, they ſaw the buſineſs.
B • ing thoſe Fellows here.
Speak Friends, how did this buſineſs happen?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: And pleaſe you, Sir, they came unto the Field,
Pluck'd off their Doublets, and they were run through.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Yes, an' pleaſe you,
With Chance-medly, I ſaw it.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: How friend, Chance-medly,
I know not what thou me • n'ſt?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Sir, he talk's like an Aſs,
Mind him not.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: But you that can talk wiſer, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: That they all drew and kill'd one another;
The iron age methoughts was come again.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Sirrah, leave off your Poetry and ſpeak toth' matter,
Who were the others that were there?
Two Swords were found,
And yet Briſac brought his home.

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: An't pleaſe you, Sir, Mounſieur D'elpech
Was there for one.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: And one Monſieur la Rock for another!

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Who, I? what a lying ſlave is this?
It is not half an hour ſince we roſe.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Sirrah, are you ſure this Gentleman was there?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Yes that I am! nay, Captain ne'r ſtare!

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Why, thou art drunk ſtill; upon my ſaith, Sir,
I have not been abroad before,
This is my firſt flight hither.

sp.speaker: La'ma.
sp.l: I can aſſure you, Sir, I lay with him,
And what he ſays is truth!

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Let their Land-lord be fetch'd, I'l ha' this examin'd,
And you, Sir, who did you ſay was there?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Monſieur la Rock,

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: H'was my Land-lord lately, but he turn'd me out of
My T • nement moſt baſely and ſcurvily.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: How came he hither, he's no man o'th Sword.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I know not I, but there he was,
And you pleaſe to give me my Oath, I'l ſwear't preſently,
And then let him ſay what he can for himſelf.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Have a care I catch you not lying,
Monſieur Cortaux, welcome;
S • w you theſe Gentlemen this morning?

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Yes, and pleaſe your Honour, one is my Gueſt;
But they both lay together this ſame night.
What ai • 'ſt thou man?

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: How ſay you, Sir, to this?

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: Why, my Father's mad or elſe miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: Thou art mad I think to pinch me ſo.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: Sirrah! you Rogue! I'le have you to the whipping-poſt,
And your Companion too,
If I do find you willfully tripping.

sp.speaker: Hoſt
sp.l: kneels—Hold Sir, I'le confeſs rather—

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: What will you confeſs, that you are an Aſs?

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: Peace Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: This ſilly fellow here and I combin'd
To accuſe Monſieur D'elpech and Monſieur La Rock:

sp.speaker: Colig.
sp.l: O humane frailty! how weak thou art!

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: Your humane frailty ſhall be try'd, Sirrah.
Away with them ſtraight,
Let them be ſoundly laſh'd.

sp.speaker: Cort.
sp.l: O mercy, Sir! he is my Heir.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: You might have bred him better.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Yes, ſo he might; nay he ſhall be whipp'd for Company;
That's my comfort; here's chance-medley for you.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: 'Tis time Monſieur La Barr muſt find this out:
May be the Colonel at laſt may tell us:
But I dare ſwear that he was fai • ly kill'd.

sp.speaker: La Mar.
sp.l: I hope there's none will queſtion that.
Since our brave Colonel was there engag'd.

sp.speaker: La Barr.
sp.l: There's none will queſtion his • ai • honour, Sir▪
Yet I would gladly know
How I have loſt my Patron now, and • hy.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: It is moſt reaſonable.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: Come, Gentlemen, this body ſhall 〈…〉
Where all our duties • it • ier may be paid.

div.head: ACT 5. SCENE 1.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: BUt are there no hopes left?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: None, but in Miracles, his Liver is quite pierc'd.
And 'tis a wonder he has not bled to death already.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: But that is ſtop • ?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Stop't, alas, Sir,
To give him time enough to ſay a Pray'r or two;
He cannot laſt an hour.

sp.speaker: La'mar.
sp.l: Truſt me, I am much griev'd.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: And ſo am I, he was a worthy brave Gentleman,
Come, lets go take out laſt farewel.

div.stage: Briſac laid in his Bed, D'orvile, Beaupres, Bellmont, Charlotte, D'elpech, La'mar.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: How is it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: The Surgeon beſt can tell.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: May we not learn the full of all this buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: A difference I had with the General,
What would you learn more,
Pray, Sir, retire, and take the Company with you,
I'm • eak, and have ſome buſineſs
I 〈◊〉 would end before I go.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Religion does forbid that we ſhould trouble you,
• e • ven grant your Pray'r • , and make ye happy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: And you, Siſter, do not leave the room,
Governour, may I entreat the preſence of your Daughter?
〈◊〉 be my laſt requeſt.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Moſt willingly! Charlotte, ſtay you here.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Adieu dear friend, I ſhall not ſee you more!

sp.speaker: La' Ma.
sp.l: May all your hopes prove proſperous,
I cannot endure to ſtay and ſee you thus!

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: And I muſt leave you like a Girle,
Blind with my tears:
I wiſh I could but do you better ſervice.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: 'Tis now too late, and yet I thank you for your wiſh.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: O Heav'ns, muſt we then part,
Curſe on my hand, it was too ſlow.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Blame not a thing that did ſo much;
Alas, we were all born to die:
And if we do anticipate the time
That bearded Elders languiſh in, we ſcape
A thouſand miſeries that they have ſurely ſtoop'd to.
Death is a bug-bear never fear'd when known:
Weep not, dear Siſter, I will leave you one
Shall be a Brother, and a kind one to you:
Will you not, Beaupres?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You cannot doubt my love to all that's yours;
But I will not diſſemble now the tie
I have upon me, to be ever kind.
Shall I have your pardon?
I would have told it you er'e long,
But ho • 'd for better opportunity
Then the ſad Fates allow me now.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: What e're it be, I do forgive thee freely,
For I dare ſooner doubt my being happy,
Then that thou e're didſt wrong me in thy friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I am her husband, Sir.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: That merits more my thanks then blame,
For it was to thy dear Arms I would bequeath her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Heav'n meant me nor ſo great a bleſſing
To have you living, and this bounteous gift.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: I give her to thee, friend, with all my heart.
Uſe her well for her poor Brothers ſake;
And, Siſter, be you ſtill to him
Such, as may make him in you love his friend,
His poor departed friend:
So, I hope you two are happy;
Now to my Love, and then I die in quiet.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Speak not of dying, Sir, it wounds my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Ha, what means that Lady, Siſter?
She weeps, ſhe weeps.
O, if thoſe tears be but for my misfortune.
I will not envy Emperours that live;
But think it greater glory thus to die,
Piti'd by the beauteous good Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You are not only piti'd but belov'd,
Beyond all what the world contains beſides.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Mock not my hopes, 'twere double death
If now I ſhould but find it otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: May I then be believ'd? O my Stars!
Is this the good you have ordain'd me?
Shew me ſuch worth,
To tell me what I've loſt.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: I know to leave this world is death,
But I leave more when I leave thee;
What heaven can I expect hereafter?
When all the Idea I can e're receive
Of happineſs, I here do leave behind me;
Will you be kind unto my memory,
My dear Charlotte!
And when your thoughts do entertain themſelves
Of me your ſervant being gone,
Remember then, Pray remember often;
How much your poor Briſac did love you!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You ſpeak as it I did intend to leave you.
No, my Briſac, I will not long out-live you.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: O yes! I do conjure you live,
By all our Love, and then I ſhall live in you:
For how ſhould I be curſt of all the world,
If I deprive it of its chiefeſt Jewel:
My ſoul ſhall wait upon you here;
My mind does tell me I ſhall bear that Office,
(For I am penitent for all my ſins)
And that will be a glorious ſtation,
More then I e're durſt hope for;
But that I gueſs I have your wiſhes for' • .

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: We'll hand in hand unto the other world,
And there confirm the union of our ſouls,
Then 'twill immortal be and we ſha'nt need
To fear a fatal ſeparation.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Deny us not, fair Maid, thy company,
We all muſt die, and be, I hope,
Together happy in the other world.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: It is not fit any of you ſhould die;
For when you' • gone,
The world will be neglected, and not own
A Subject worth a care;
You ſhall not think of leaving one another;
Dear friend, would you thus leave alone
My deareſt Miſtreſs, and your poor Bellmont;
Charlotte in you may ſee what I have lov'd?
And in her friendſhip to you think on me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Whilſt memory retains a place,
Or life but motion giveth to my heart;
Each breath I draw, and every bow I make,
Shall be for my Briſac:
The organs of my ſoul ſhall frame no ſound,
But what ſhall eccho ſtill my dear Briſac;
Maſter of all my hopes and all my joy:
Poor fickle joy, alas, how ſoon thou leav'ſt me?
Never, O never, to return again!

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: And you, dear friend, when you ſhall ſee that face,
That much adored perſon I have lov'd,
Pay her the zeal of all your friendſhip to me;
And, Siſter, as you ever did affect
Your Brother, turn that kindneſſe all
To my Charlotte, and to Beaupres your duty.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Your Major, Sir, is come to take his leave.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Heavens bleſs my Colonel! how is't, Sir?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: O Beaupres, come hither, I had forgot to tell you;
But I grow wondrous faint;
Have a care of Maligni.
Oh Charlotte, your hand, for I am going;

Farewel, farewel; I
〈◊〉 no more.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Farewel the thoughts of worldly things;
What are th • Pomps of greateſt Kings?
But empty titles State foreſhew,
Idols, we make, to which we bow;
Nothing that's certain here below,
But death; and certain that we know
How glorious is the fabrick, when,
Ill to the Maker likens men;
But this the cleereſt ever was,
Retain'd the brittleneſs of glaſs.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Through which we ought to ſee how fair
Are Bliſſes that eternal are;
Led by perſwaſion of our blood,
We here expect a certain good,
And frame our beſt of what is worſt!
Since by great Heav'n the earth we curſt.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: My thoughts to Heav'n their wiſhes ſend;
And to Heav'ns will in reverence bend;
Leave tempting me thou diſmal care,
Miſtreſs of ruine and deſpair;
The ſtrings of my poor heart, I'm ſure,
Are not ſo ſtrong they can endure
This cruel weight: then be thou gone,
And leave my Love to act alone.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Maligni, ha, canſt thou weep?
I ſhall enamou • 'd grow of what I could not love before.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Poor Major, What have we here loſt?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I Madam, the world can yield no recompence for this.

sp.speaker: Chair.
sp.l: He bad us have a care of him dead!
Sir, remember, pray, to do it as you love
Your dying friend, O my ſoul!
That 〈◊〉 live to ſpeak him.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Alas, my Colonel took care, you ſee, at laſt,
For me, unworthy me; I ſhall grow blind with grief;

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Come Major, help to lead theſe Ladies forth,
And call me now your friend;
Since he commanded hath this friendly tie.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange we ſhould not learn
A perfecter accompt of all this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Cannot Beaupres inform you?

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: He ſeems as ignorant as we.

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: And I dare ſwear he is ſo:
You two, I hope, are reconci • 'd.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: O yes, the General did it this morning.

sp.speaker: D'elph.
sp.l: How? this morning! why, were you with him this morning?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: No, not I; who ſays I was?

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: I did underſtand you ſo.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I was miſtaken, ſo were you too; God buy.

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: What the Devil's this?
Hey paſs and repaſs, this Fellow grows ſo • urly,
He'll have his brains beaten out ere long;
He's like a mad dog, ſnarls and bites at every body.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: I, and no body knows wherefore;
Sure his brain's ad • le.

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: Nay that it ever was ſince I knew him;
But he's much alter'd, h' us'd to be
An honeſt plain blunt Fellow;
Now ſo cap • icious! out on' • !

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Who cares?—but to our buſineſs:
Who doſt thou think will carry now the Regiment?

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: There is much talk of young Beaupres;
Though it of right belongs to Maligni.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: He's a man that has no friend,
And I'm afraid deſerves none:
Yet he will buffle hard before he loſe his Right:
The other's a worthy youth;
Though I dare ſwear he will not much ſeek for it.

sp.speaker: La' Ma.
sp.l: I love him for my Colonels ſake,
H' was his faithful friend.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſtill my ſtudy how to ſerve him.
O Major! ow • 'ſt man?
Ha, weeping, why I thought thy breeding in the Wars
Had dry'd that fountain up;
Yet truſt me it does become thee;
I ſhall e'en bear thee company.

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: We have all loſt a worthy man;
But Fa • e has call'd him to a better place.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I hope ſo.

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: This may prove well for you:
You are the next in place, for to ſucceed him▪

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: It never can prove well,
I having loſt ſo brave a Colonel;
But Gentlemen let me entreat,
You will to morrow morning order give
That all your men draw up together
Without Saint Denis Gate, and there receive
Some further orders:

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: We will not fail;

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: O! I had forgot to tell you,
(My grief doth overwhelm my memory,)
Young Beaupreſs is married to Bellmont,
The ſiſter of our late Colonel,
Here privately, ſince that they came to Town;

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: Did Briſac know ſo much before be dy'd?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Yes, yes! but not when they were marry'd,
He had bequeath'd her in his will to him,
And with her all his fortune.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: 'Twas noble Friendſhip in him,
I wiſh them joy and happineſs.

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: What Rumors that, about Beaupres ſucceſſ •• n?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I know not, I, nor care not.

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: If there be any ſuch report,
It ſprings from this occaſion,
Beaupres did, when his Uncle loſt his life,
Pretend unto this Regiment;
But young Briſac
Had then the promiſe of the firſt that fell,
For ſome brave Action he had done;
When Beaupres with him joyn'd in all,
As being long Comrades, forc'd it upon him,
And would not once diſpute it,
You ſince have ſeen he ſerv'd a Volunteer,
And would have no Command amongſt us.

sp.speaker: La' Mar.
sp.l: Something I knew before;
But was not quite ſo perfect in the ſtory,
We ſhall obey your laſt Commands,
Adieu Major.—

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: He ha' th' Regiment, ha, ha, ha!
I, ſo he ſhall, that's my good Boy, make much on't;
Soft, ſoft ye fools, I have rods in piſs
For him, and for his curious Minx
She us'd me ſweetly; well, I muſt not truſt her,
She know's I am a Rogue,
And ſeeing me grow great with him
She may diſcover our laſt evenings walk,
How am I now beſet with my own plots,
That fool Boutefeu, and he, for ought I know,
May grow to a right Underſtanding,
Ha! what becomes of me then? I have i •
And each on th'other ſhall ſecure my fate.—

div.stage: Charlotte, held on a bed by Mariane Francibel, Dorville.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Pray, Sirs, let me go, you uſe me too unkindly,
I never did any of you ſuch wrong;

sp.speaker: Dorv.
sp.l: Take comfort, my dear Girl,
Thy father begs it of thee!

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: Why, I did beg of Heaven, and that was deaf,
Deaf to my Zealous prayers;
Ile never pray agen: but I will ſing
My ſelf into his bleſt Society.

div.head: SONG.
div.l: The Bells were rung, and the Maſs was ſung,
And all was for my Billy,
And all my friends my death had ſworn,
I would have none but Willy.

sp.l: Hey, ho! break thou fooliſh heart;
Why doſt thou throb, and ſnub
Like Girls that are whipt,
Indeed I could be angry thou art ſo long a breaking.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: She's much diſtemper'd, Sir,
Madam, for Heaven's ſake take patience to you.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.l: What man is that?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is your Father, Madam!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: O pray, Sir, be gone: alas poor man! he weeps too.
Is it for Briſac you weep? nay then, pray ſtay,
We will all weep, ſhall we not? he would have wept
For me moſt bitterly, do not you think he would?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes ſurely, Madam.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Alas poor man! come let me dry your cheeks:
Truly I take it very kindly of you, that you will weep
For my Briſac: did you lament my Mother ſo?
Would ſhe were with you now to comfort you, and I
Were in her place.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: Peace, my dear Child,
Thou like a tangled bird doſt beat
And fret thy ſelf to death.

lg.l: Willy was • air, Willy was ſtou • ,
Willy was like the Lilly;
And Willy promis'd to marry me.

sp.l: O! but he could not; for he dy'd, or elſe he would
Have kept his promiſe: was ever poor maid
So couzen'd; ſpeak, were you ever cou • en'd?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: No truly, Mada • .

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: May be ſome Muſick may ſtill her ſpirits, Sir:
Shall my Siſter ſing?

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: I Pray let her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sing Siſter! prethee ſing!
Lady preſerve the Title of your heart,
And ne're commit ſo raſh a deed,
As when your Lover doth depart,
You may not leave off ſorrow with your weed:
Spoil not what once was thought ſo fair▪
But quench remaining • i • e with a • ear▪
And bury, when the next does come,
All ſad remembrance in this Tomb.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Away, thou art out of tune and ſence,
If I needs muſt hear Muſick,
Let it be my poor Boy's Voice;
He once could pleaſe me with his melancholly Songs,
Pray, let him ſing.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: Any thing to pleaſe thee, poor Charlotte.
Beyond the malice of abuſive fate
I now am grown, and in that ſtate
My heart ſhall mourn the loſs it has receiv'd,
When of its only joy it was bereav'd;
The Woods with ecchoes do abound,
And each of them return the ſound
Of my Amintor's name; alas, he's dead,
And with him all my joys are fled,
Willow, Willow, Willow muſt I wear,
For ſweet Amintor's dead, why was my dear.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She's faln into a ſlumber.

sp.speaker: D'or.
sp.l: No noiſe, make the room dark you do convey her to.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I could not gueſs ſo much before.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: P'heu! that can be no reaſon, Sir,
I never did pretend to her,
It's true, I've ſeen her often:
But marri'd are they; art ſure of that?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: He and ſhe told me ſo themſelves,
I had ſome conference with her alone;
But what a Rogue am I!
I was commanded to be ſilent,
And yet this tongue of mine
It is ſo forward ſtill to do you good!

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Why, Major, this to me!
If it be ought that I ſhould know?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Alas, Sir, it concerns no other man.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: And do you doubt my full diſcretion?
You and I have ſtill been friends.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: And I am ſtill the readi'ſt man on earth
To do you ſervice,
But a Ladies honour
The Secret, Sir, is none of mine, but hers;
And I cannot diſpoſe on't to your truſt
Without her leave,
She ſays ſhe mainly doubts your carriage on't.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Doubts my carriage?
I have been truſted before now,
With half this Ceremony.
If I can do her ſervice tell me,
For ſhe's a very pretty woman,
And I'l do't, if you wont, chuſe!

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Do her a ſervice?
'Tis to do one to your ſelf,
The greateſt too that e're your hopes could aim at.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Prethee, what is't, Major!
You torture me with theſe delays.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: You never gave a cauſe to young Beaupres
Why he ſhould hate you ſo.

sp.speaker: Bnut.
sp.l: Never I, till to'ther night!

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: P'heu! that was only a requital
To his unkindneſs,
I'm ſure you mean't it ſo.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: But never any thing before?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Why, then he does ſuſpect
As much as I am now acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Let him ſuſpect his heart out,
Prethee what is't?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: But you will not be rul'd,
And think it is below you thus to ſneak,
And hide your ſelf for ſuch a Lady.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I will be rul'd, I ſwear I will:
Thou ſtill ſhalt be my guide.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: The fair Bellmont does dote upon you, Sir:
Pray, what Charms have you made uſe of.
Thus to enſnare ſo fair a woman?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: You do not jeſt with me?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Not I,
Nay, if you hold me for a V • llain,
I've done.
I knew my fooliſh tongue would be too forward.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Nay, now you are unkind;
But does ſhe love me ſo,
I'l to her ſtrait,
I wou'd croſs hell to meet ſo fair a Lady.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Why look you, Sir, how raſh you are?
Take your own courſe,
This way ſhe'll never ſee you.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 then? dear Major, do you direct me.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 you procure a Fryar's habit?

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Ha—Yes, the Chaplain of our Regiment has one,
He us'd to preach 〈◊〉 ; I can take his.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Do then, ſhe ſhall meet you by the River ſide below the Garden walk, make haſte, and ask no queſtions.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I'm gone; farewell! dear Maligni,
And if I thrive, command my life.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Yes! I think I ſhall command thy life,
Or by thy hand be maſter of Beaupre's.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: How doſt thou, Maligni?
What, all alone?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Sir, I was thinking with my ſelf,
You 〈◊〉 forgot, I'm ſure, our laſt diſcourſe,
Where you grew angry, about Boutefeu.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Hang him rude ſlave,
〈…〉 think on him.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: And the 〈◊〉 thinks 〈◊〉 ſo much his friend,
There's nought he 〈◊〉 hides from me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: His ſecrets ſurely are not worth the hearing.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: They may concern you, Sir, in time.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Me, alas, I do defie his malice.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: But, Sir, there are ſome private hits.
And thoſe but ſeldom ſmart.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: If he be ſtout, as I do think he is,
He will abhor to murder any man
That ready is to do him noble reaſon:
And if a coward;
He will not dare to think on' • .

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Nay, on my Conſcience, he'll ne're murder you▪
But, Sir, by this I find, you are ſtill at odds,
May be 〈◊〉 Lady does it for the beſt.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: My Lady! what of her?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I ſay, ſhe, may be, ſooths him up,
To make you friends.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: She ſooth him up! why, ſhe ne're ſpeaks to him.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Nay, there you are miſtaken, to my knowledge, Sir.
And he came thence ſo jocund and ſo gay:
She has much power over him!
That is moſt certain, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What's this I hear?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: But ſhe ſhould chide him,
The quarrel was very prepoſterous,
And might wrong her fame.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: 'Tis true, 'tis true! what an Owl am I?
Not to reflect on that.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: But he was jealous of your better fortune.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: He jealous of my Bellmont?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I, I, all the world might ſee that in his carriage,
But, why ſhe ſhould conſent to meet
A man diſguis'd, and privately.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I know ſhe will not.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: But if I prove it to you,
Shall I then be believ'd?
She is the Siſter of my Colonel,
And now your Wife, whom I have ever lov'd,
She may ſome indiſcretions now commit
Will lie as heavy on her as a Crime.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: My honeſt, honeſt, Maligni,
〈◊〉 this, and tie me ever to thy ſervice.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Take you no notice, go, I'l bring ye where
You ſhall need no atteſt but from your eyes—
〈◊〉 , theſe Trout's a man may tickle from their Senſes.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: I have the habit, Major.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Make much on't Boy; but keep your ſword about ye
Under your Coat, in caſe of danger to prevent the worſt.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Thank's, Major, for your care:
I did intend ſo much.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: 'Tis not my fault if either of you live;
Fall both, And then Im • certain I ſhall thrive—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Go ſee how my poor ſiſter Charlotte does,
And if ſhe be awake.

sp.speaker: Luyſ.
sp.l: I ſhall, Madam.—

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: How ſullen is my fate,
Thus to begin in mourning after marriage,
My Lords poor heart is over-charg'd with grief,
And we like Turtles grieve for poor Briſac;
Poor youth he was both Friend and Brother;
O Major! you are welcome, and I hope,
You have as well forgot the will to ſin,
As I have freely now forgot your fault.
You ſee the frailty of man's eſtate,
And then the ſure account we all muſt give,
Come be not ſad, this Counſel I do'nt mean
As a reproach, but for your real good;
For I do finde my brother lov'd you much.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Why did the Heav'ns create you then ſo fair,
O hide thoſe Eyes, for they would make
An auſtere Anchorite in Love with ſin.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You counſel well:
Hereafter Ile not move
This vail when you ſhall be in preſence.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: 'Twas the good Counſel of your Ghoſtly Father,
Who now ha's eas'd my ſoul
Of a moſt heavy burthen it ſuſtain'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Truly, I do rejoyce in your Converſion.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: He told me, Madam, he would ſpeak with you,
Alone, without acquainting of your husband,
Matter of Moment he pretends it is.

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: What ſhould it be? can you not gueſs, good Maj •• ?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Yes! I believe about the difference
Happen'd between Boutefeu and him;
I have a Letter from him to you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: To me! prethee let's ſee' • .

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: The Prieſt ha's brought him to confeſs his fault,
But honour will not let him do't to your Lord,
And you are thought the fitteſt Medium now.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I wiſh I might prevail with them for peace,
How is ſhe, Wench? does ſhe ſtill ſleep?—

sp.speaker: Luyſ.
sp.l: No, Madam, ſhe's awake,
And 'tis a woful ſight to ſee her ſo.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I will go Viſit her.
Major, I ſhall remember what you told me of,
And will not fail to meet the father,
But pray where is't?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Below the Garden, by the River • ide.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Here, Luyſon, keep this Letter—

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Nay, ſtay you here.

sp.speaker: Luyſ.
sp.l: My Lady will chide, I dare not,
Ile meet you here anon.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: What letter's that, let's ſee't?

sp.speaker: Luyſ.
sp.l: Fy Major, oh here's my Lord—forces the letter from her▪

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Who was that juſt now
Parted from you?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Your Lady's woman,
I am great with her, ſtay let me ſee the Letter
She ha's ſtoln.
Madam!
I ſhall not fail to meet you neer the garden,
By the River • ide, and there be obedient, in what
Ever you ſhall think moſt fit,
Why, look ye, Sir!
Thus unexpectedly I find a way
To keep my promiſe with you:

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: 'Tis not his hand,
He dares not write thus to her:

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Are you ſo perfect in his Character?
Me-think's it is his hand.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I never did believe that he could write;
A ſenſe-leſs brute; but I grow fool in Words
And idle paſſion is for want of deeds.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: What deeds?
Heaven guard your breſt from evil thoughts,
You will not, ſure, conclude that there is harm in this.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: No, no, meet a man privately,
Diſguis'd as you do tell me,
One that durſt wrong me too, her husband,
Moſt excellent Meaning ſure there is in this,
O, I could rear her from my memory,
Nay, • ear the heart that ever did contain
So baſe a Gueſt, as her baſe Whoriſh Love.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Fye, Sir, 'tis not ſo bad yet.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: 'Tis not the body, but the mind
Can ever make it bad,
I'de rather have my wi • e 'twice raviſh'd,
Then once dare think the means how ſhe may act it,
But thou art honeſt Maligni
And know'ſt not half the cunning of theſe Women.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Alas, Sir, I.
You ſe • , Sir, in her Carriage I was Cozen'd,
Nay, her Brothers eyes were ſeal'd too,
And yet that was not ſuch a Monſtrous Crime,
That ſhe ſhould take ſuch care in the Concealment,
How cloſe ſhe'd prove in matter of more moment.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: And I, good-Natur'd Fool,
Read it obedience to my ſtrict Command.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Nay, may 〈◊〉 'twas ſo,
But ſhe's good Natur'd too,
And, I would have you ſtill avoy'd all ſcandal.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Good natur'd; ha?
Come lead me to this ſight,
I'm • ick till I be there,
And ſicker ſhall be far when I have ſeen it:

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I will not be your guide,
If you 〈…〉 ought when you have ſeen it.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Not be my Guide?
Thou ſhalt,
Or I will cut your throat, Officious Sir▪
Do you pretend to tell me this
Out of meer friendſhip? thinking to ſooth me up
To low diſhonour? You ſhould have held your tongue
If you did mean it, knowing me:
But now conduct me where I may ſee them both,
As thou didſt tell me too,
Or I will cut thy throat, becauſe thou knewſt not me,
And yet doſt know her weakneſs.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Come, put up your Sword,
Or keep it drawn ſtill againſt your Friend;
'Twill be no argument of courage, Sir,
Nor of much honeſty:
I will diſcover all I can unto you;
And if you raſhly deal, then blame not me;
For I grow mad to ſee your excellent Nature
Thus Fever-ſhook by a fond Womans fault;
But let me ſtil • perſwade your wiſer thoughts
To fly all choler in your undertakings.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: I'le do no raſh unſeaſonable act,
Without a full examination,
That I'le promiſe thee.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Nay, if you come once to examining
You put them to • guard, and they'l defend
All queſtions you can then but offer to them.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Why, as you pleaſe?
But Boutefeu is very cholerick,
He'l ſcarce endure examination
Without the meaſuring of this.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Would there were all my miſchief.
Prethee lets go, I ſtand on thorn • .

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Come, if I can I will prevent your horns.

div.stage: Enter Bouteſeu like a Frier in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: She is not here yet.
Methinks I look like Frier Bacon▪
But I had better been ſtudying what to ſay;
Hang Speeches, I came to do;
For ſhe likes me already, then what need I talk?
O my ſweet Maligni!
I' • e ſue for thee to my Siſter,
An t' wilt, for this kindneſs:
No Soul in Love, fond Boy, the Worlds great Soul.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Moſt Reverend Sir, you ſee I have not fail'd
In my obedience to your Meſſage ſent.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Nor will I ever fail whilſt I do breath
To be the humbleſt of your Servants, Lady.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Father! I cry you mercy, you are not the man
I took you for.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Yes but I am, Lady; See my hair is only put back▪

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Hell and Furies! Stay me not:

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Ha! her Husband, with Maligni too!
O Villain; I am betraid;
Have comfort, Lady, I can defend ye well.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Me! I know ye not.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: But I do you.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: 'Twas baſe; here was the nobler mark,
As I am man, and therefore thou—

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Come, come, ye dog, thus I can muzzle ye.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: No, not yet.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Yes, now 'twill do, thus, doubly thus.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Had I but done the deed
It would not trouble me half ſo much to dye thus.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: As you did e're love Heav'n
Hear me but ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis now too late.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: But I will hear her ſpeak,
And learn the truth from dying mouths.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Then keep them company.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Heav'ns guard my dear Beaupres.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Baſe treacherous Villain—
What didſt thou mean in this?
Hey, Bask! help me to ty this dog:
Come, lead them to my Cloſet,
There I will learn the truth;
This place is too much open to the eye.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: Pray, Madam, ere you go

Tell me one thing, and then I dye in quiet •
▪
Did you e're ſend for me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Not as I hope for mercy;
Nor did I till now know you.

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Who did perſwade you hither?
