sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.l: A baſe malicious Villain, and a Knave;
I find I was betray'd by my own folly.
Beaupres, give me thy hand;
As e're I hope to come at Heaven
'Tis Maligni has wrong'd both thee and me,
And this fair virtuous Lady.
This as I'm dying I am bound to tell.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What canſt thou ſay to this?

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I will ſay nothing but thou art an Aſs,
Though I have miſt my aim.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Convey him, Sirrah, to my Cloſet,
And kill him rather then permit eſcape.
But O, what torments of Eternal Hell
Afflict my murther'd Soul!
Bellmont my fair! my dear Bellmont!
Could all the malice of a bloody Rogue
Tempt me to wound this breſt!
The Fountain of my Pleaſures, all my Joys!
O, my curſt Stars!
No bolt in Heaven to ſtrike ſo foul a Murtherer?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: The Heavens ſhall ſure forgive thee my Beaupres,
If ever I get thither:
For I will be th • Interceſſour ſtill,
And knowing it was Love too much betray'd,
I will not grieve to dye thy Martyr;
But when I am gone
Believe my Honour ſtill as fair,
And that I ſtill did love my dear Beaupres,
Farewel, one kiſs, ſo

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ye Angels take her to your Guardianſhip.
Whilſt I muſt howl my fault ſo loud,
That Beaſts that hear the diſmal ſound
Shall frighted ſtand, and men with horrour ſweat,
Whilſt they imagine but my Agony.
O Bask, is he ſafe, here ſet theſe bodies up,
Now call the Governour
And all thou ſeeſt of my acquaintance,
Hark thee one word.
Thus like a Pilgrim, fore his honour'd Saint,
I offer up oblations of my Vows;
But like a ſinner ſteel'd in vice
I muſt deſpair the mercy I do call for;
For thou art cold my Girle, my poor Bellmont,
And though thy charity to'th laſt did blaze,
It was a fire will conſume my ſoul,
My eaſie couzen'd ſoul, which ought to loſe
Its immortality, ſince it did reaſon lack;
Come all ye Furies laſh me from this ſight,
But now I think on't, this is a Sanctuary,
No, I will firſt perform one act of juſtice,
(That I ſhould talk of juſtice now!)
And then I will deliver to your rage
All that I can of me—
Yet let thy mercy, heaven,
Allow me but her ſight, for my relief
Her pleaſing ſight—
For ſhe did ſpeak forgiveneſs at her death;
And wilt thou uſe ſo prodigal a mercy,
No, my Bellmont, I need no weapon for my death,
Grief for my fault will ſtop my breath.

div.stage: Enter Maligni gag'd and blinded with a Handkerchief twixt two ſervants.
div.l: So ſet him there
And when I give the word, hark ye,
He not deſerves a worthier hand,
What made thee, Hell-hound, thus abuſe my ſoul,
Had'ſt thou no pity left thee in thy breſt,
Yet this ſame ſight would make Alecto weep;
Thou Cruel Dog—
And I more Cruel Fool—

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: I will not anſwer thee, do what thou wilt

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Away with him to Execution,
I hear em' coming—
sp.stage: Enter Dorville, D'elpech, La' March, La Barr, Attendants.
sp.l: Moſt worthy, Sir, why, I have call'd you here,
That ſight will beſt inform you.

sp.speaker: Dorv.
sp.l: Ha! dead! Boutefeu too in a Fryars weed.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You'l wonder more when I dare boldly tell you,
'Twas I that kill'd them both.

sp.speaker: Dorv.
sp.l: Diſarm him ſome of you,

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: within—O, O! ye Cruel Dogs!

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: The firſt that does attempt it ſtraight ſhall find
The folly's great, when I m' reſolv'd to die!
But hear me quietly ſome few moments,
I promiſe to reſign it then:

sp.speaker: Dorv.
sp.l: Will you therewith not do ſome harm firſt?
Not on your ſelf I mean?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I ſhall not need,
That have ſuch killing objects 'fore my eyes.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: O, O, O!

sp.speaker: Dorv.
sp.l: What voyce is that!

sp.speaker: Beaup.
sp.l: Say, Sir, I beſt can tell you,
The voice it is of one
That wrought me to a miſchief, none but he,
So wicked Villain as he was,
Could ever give a birth to.

sp.speaker: Luyſ.
sp.l: O! my Lady! my dear Lady!

sp.speaker: Dorv.
sp.l: Peace, thou fooliſh woman!
But who is't, pray, Sir? He ſeem's to be wounded.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: That horrid Monſter Maligni,
Poor Bellmont could he behold thy Face
And plo ſuch Ruine to thy Lovelineſs?

sp.speaker: Luyſ.
sp.l: Did he do this?
H' would have raviſh'd her once before in the garden.

sp.speaker: Malig.
sp.l: Peace! Devil! peace!

sp.speaker: Luyſ.
sp.l: Nay, it ſhall all out,
Ha's tempted me ſeveral times to leave ſome Letters
In her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I find my ſoul's a ſleeting after her's
And you'l have time enough t'examine this,
See, Sir, the Sacrifice of Innocence,—
sp.stage: Malig. diſcover'd peirc't with a ſtake.
sp.l: Now take my ſword, 'tis not in Surgeons Art
To cure the fractures of a Broken heart!
Beſides that Villain ha's been buſie here;
Forgive me Dear Bellmont! forgive a Crime
Caus'd by my too much Love.—

sp.speaker: D'elp.
sp.l: I ever did ſuſpect that Maligni.

sp.speaker: La. Mar.
sp.l: H'was a ſubtle and a Cruel Villain:

sp.speaker: Luyſ.
sp.l: But, Sir, your daughter.

sp.speaker: Dorv.
sp.l: Ha! what of her?

sp.speaker: Layſ.
sp.l: Is dead? poor Lady dy'd diſtracted with her grief.

sp.speaker: Dorv.
sp.l: I wiſh that mine
Could do that favourable office;
Heaven's how have I deſerv'd
Theſe ſad afflictions?

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: The beſt of cure and remedy is patience,
Then take it to you, Sir,
Remember Vertue call's upon you ſort.

sp.speaker: D'orv.
sp.l: But, Sir, of late,
Vertues rewards are ſlow,
And I am too much oppreſt with cruel grief,
To ſtir my paſſions by her Moral rules!
O my poor Girl!
How cruel was thy fate?

sp.speaker: D'elpe.
sp.l: Be not ſo much dejected, Sir!
We muſt ſubmit to him that makes all even.
And never Spurn againſt the will of Heaven.
